The patients were assessed for outcomes such as healing, stability of the titanium plates, and functional results. Radiographic assessments were also performed to evaluate the integration of the titanium plates with the surrounding bone. The results showed that mandibular reconstruction using titanium plates in irradiated patients had favorable outcomes in terms of healing, stability, and functional results. Furthermore, radiographic assessments indicated successful integration of the titanium plates with the surrounding bone. This technique offers a promising option for mandibular reconstruction in irradiated patients with mandibular defects.

Angina, ischemia, and effort tolerance with vasodilating beta-blockers. Angina is a common symptom in patients with ischemic heart disease and often limits their effort tolerance. Vasodilating beta-blockers have been widely used in the management of angina to alleviate symptoms and improve exercise capacity. However, the optimal dose of vasodilating beta-blockers in this context remains unclear. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the association between different doses of vasodilating beta-blockers and effort tolerance in patients with angina and ischemia. A total of 150 patients with stable angina and myocardial ischemia who were treated with vasodilating beta-blockers were included. Effort tolerance was assessed using exercise testing. The results showed that high-dose vasodilating beta-blocker therapy was associated with significantly improved effort tolerance compared to low-dose therapy. These findings suggest that higher doses of vasodilating beta-blockers may be more effective in improving effort tolerance in patients with angina and ischemia. Further studies are needed to confirm these results and determine the optimal dose of vasodilating beta-blockers in this patient population.

Strokes in African-Americans. Strokes in African-Americans have long been recognized as a significant health concern due to their higher incidence and greater severity compared to other racial and ethnic groups. Various factors contribute to this disparity, including higher prevalence of traditional risk factors such as hypertension, diabetes, and obesity, as well as socioeconomic and psychosocial factors. Additionally, there may be genetic and biological differences that make African-Americans more susceptible to strokes. Improved understanding of these factors is crucial for developing targeted prevention and treatment strategies. This review aims to summarize the current knowledge on the epidemiology, risk factors, and underlying mechanisms of strokes in African-Americans. By addressing these issues, healthcare professionals can work towards reducing the burden of stroke and improving outcomes in this high-risk population.

Does age affect outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation? We examined the relation between age and outcomes in patients treated for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Seattle, Wash. We conducted a retrospective study to determine if age influences the outcomes of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in patients treated for cardiac arrest in Seattle, Washington. A total of 500 patients were included in the study, with ages ranging from 18 to 90 years. Outcome measures included return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) and survival to hospital discharge. Our results showed that younger patients (<65 years) had significantly higher rates of ROSC compared to older patients (≥65 years) (p<0.05). However, there was no significant difference in survival to hospital discharge between the two age groups. These findings suggest that age may affect the initial success of CPR, but does not have a significant impact on long-term survival outcomes in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest patients. Further studies are needed to better understand the factors influencing survival in different age groups.

Surgical treatment of aneurysm or dissection involving the ascending aorta and aortic arch, utilizing circulatory arrest and retrograde cerebral perfusion. Surgical treatment of aneurysm or dissection involving the ascending aorta and aortic arch often requires circulatory arrest and retrograde cerebral perfusion. In this study, we evaluated the outcomes and complications associated with this surgical technique. A total of 45 patients who underwent surgery for ascending aorta and aortic arch pathology were included in the study. Circulatory arrest was achieved using deep hypothermia and selective antegrade cerebral perfusion. Retrograde cerebral perfusion was used during the period of circulatory arrest. The overall mortality rate was 8.9%, with three patients experiencing postoperative neurological complications. Other complications included renal failure requiring dialysis and respiratory insufficiency. Despite the high-risk nature of the procedure, surgical treatment with circulatory arrest and retrograde cerebral perfusion appears to be an effective approach with acceptable outcomes in patients with ascending aortic pathology.

Matched group study of surgical resection versus cobalt-60 plaque radiotherapy for primary choroidal or ciliary body melanoma.  We report the results of a nonrandomized, matched-group, survival and visual preservation study of patients with a choroidal or ciliary body melanoma managed by microsurgical resection of the tumor versus cobalt-60 episcleral plaque radiotherapy. In this study, we compared the outcomes of surgical resection and cobalt-60 plaque radiotherapy in patients with primary choroidal or ciliary body melanoma. A nonrandomized matched-group design was used to match patients based on age, tumor size, and location. Survival rates and visual preservation were evaluated as primary endpoints.

Our findings showed that patients who underwent microsurgical resection had comparable survival rates to those treated with cobalt-60 plaque radiotherapy. However, visual preservation was significantly better in the surgical resection group. This suggests that surgical resection may offer an advantage in terms of maintaining visual function in patients with primary choroidal or ciliary body melanoma.

Further studies are needed to confirm these results and evaluate long-term outcomes. Nonetheless, our study highlights the importance of considering both survival rates and visual preservation when choosing the appropriate treatment modality for patients with primary choroidal or ciliary body melanoma.

Primary lymphoma of the central nervous system in two children with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Primary lymphoma of the central nervous system (CNS) is a rare malignancy, particularly in the pediatric population. We present two cases of primary CNS lymphoma in children with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). Both patients presented with neurological symptoms, including seizures and focal deficits. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the brain. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis demonstrated elevated levels of lymphocytes and protein. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Treatment consisted of high-dose chemotherapy along with combination antiretroviral therapy for their underlying AIDS. Despite aggressive management, both patients experienced disease progression and ultimately succumbed to complications of CNS lymphoma. This case series highlights the aggressive nature and poor prognosis of primary CNS lymphoma in children with AIDS and underscores the importance of early diagnosis and multidisciplinary management.

Wrist flexion as an adjunct to the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a common condition characterized by compression of the median nerve in the wrist. Current diagnostic methods, such as electrodiagnostic tests, have limitations in sensitivity and specificity. This study aimed to evaluate the use of wrist flexion as an adjunct to the diagnosis of CTS. A total of 100 patients with suspected CTS were included in the study. Wrist flexion was assessed using a goniometer, and electrodiagnostic tests were conducted. The results showed that patients with CTS had significantly reduced wrist flexion compared to those without CTS. Incorporating wrist flexion into the diagnostic process improved the sensitivity and specificity of CTS diagnosis. Wrist flexion can serve as a valuable adjunct to aid in the accurate diagnosis of CTS.

Critical review of gangliosides and thyrotropin-releasing hormone in peripheral neuromuscular diseases. Peripheral neuromuscular diseases are characterized by the dysfunction of the peripheral nerves or muscles, leading to weakness, atrophy, and impaired movement. Gangliosides, a type of glycolipid, and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) have been investigated for their potential therapeutic effects in these conditions. This critical review examines the current evidence on the use of gangliosides and TRH in peripheral neuromuscular diseases.

Multiple studies have evaluated the effects of gangliosides and TRH on nerve regeneration, muscle strength, and motor function in various peripheral neuromuscular disease models. Findings suggest that gangliosides play a role in promoting nerve regeneration and restoring muscle strength, while TRH may have neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects. However, the majority of these studies are preclinical, and clinical trials are limited, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions.

Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms of action and potential clinical benefits of gangliosides and TRH in peripheral neuromuscular diseases. The development of well-designed clinical trials is necessary to provide reliable evidence and guide clinical practice in this field.

Primary defect in alpha-adrenergic responsiveness in patients with varicose veins.  Responsiveness of superficial hand veins to local infusions of noradrenaline was compared in patients with primary varicose veins and in healthy volunteers by use of the dorsal hand vein technique. Patients with primary varicose veins demonstrated a significantly lower alpha-adrenergic responsiveness compared to healthy volunteers. The percentage increase in vein diameter in response to noradrenaline infusion was significantly lower in the varicose vein group compared to the control group. This suggests that there is a primary defect in the alpha-adrenergic receptor pathway in patients with varicose veins, leading to decreased vasoconstriction. These findings may help elucidate the underlying mechanisms responsible for the development and progression of varicose veins and provide new insights into potential therapeutic targets for this common vascular disorder.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI) is a peptide hormone that has been shown to play a role in the regulation of gastrointestinal mucosal homeostasis. Aberrant expression of PSTI has been reported in various gastrointestinal malignancies, including colorectal cancer. However, the expression pattern of PSTI in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa remains poorly understood. In this study, we investigated the immunohistochemical expression of PSTI in 50 normal colonic mucosa samples and 50 colonic adenocarcinoma samples. Our results showed that PSTI expression was significantly decreased in colonic adenocarcinomas compared to normal colonic mucosa. Furthermore, a subset of adenocarcinomas exhibited complete loss of PSTI expression. Interestingly, we observed a positive correlation between PSTI expression and tumor grade, with well-differentiated tumors showing higher PSTI expression compared to poorly differentiated tumors. These findings suggest a potential role of PSTI in the pathogenesis of colorectal cancer and highlight its potential as a diagnostic and prognostic marker for this malignancy. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms regulating PSTI expression in colorectal cancer.

Skeletal muscle depressed calcium and phosphofructokinase in chronic heart failure are upregulated by captopril--a double-blind, placebo-controlled study.  The effects of the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor captopril, after treatment for 5-6 weeks with 25 mg t. We conducted a double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess the effects of captopril on skeletal muscle metabolism in patients with chronic heart failure. After a treatment period of 5-6 weeks with 25 mg of captopril, we measured the levels of calcium and phosphofructokinase in skeletal muscle. The study included 12 patients who were randomly assigned to receive either captopril or placebo. We found that captopril treatment significantly upregulated the levels of calcium (p = 0.02) and phosphofructokinase (p = 0.01) in skeletal muscle compared to placebo. This suggests that captopril has a beneficial effect on skeletal muscle metabolism in patients with chronic heart failure. No adverse effects were observed during the study. Our results highlight the potential of captopril as a treatment option for patients with skeletal muscle dysfunction in chronic heart failure.

Hemodynamic and endocrine effects of mental stress in untreated borderline hypertension. The present study aimed to assess the hemodynamic and endocrine effects of mental stress in untreated borderline hypertension. A total of 50 individuals with borderline hypertension and 50 normotensive controls were enrolled in the study. All participants underwent a mental stress test, including arithmetic tasks and public speaking, while their blood pressure, heart rate, and plasma levels of catecholamines and cortisol were measured before, during, and after the stress test. It was found that individuals with borderline hypertension had a significantly greater increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure during the mental stress test compared to normotensive controls. Moreover, plasma levels of norepinephrine and cortisol were significantly higher in the borderline hypertension group during and after the stress test. These findings suggest that mental stress elicits exaggerated hemodynamic and endocrine responses in individuals with borderline hypertension, which may contribute to the progression of their condition.

Recombination between two 14-bp homologous sequences as the mechanism for gene deletion in factor IX Seattle 1.  Factor IXSeattle 1 is a 10-kb intragenic deletion identified in a family that has hemophilia B.  By sequencing across the site of the deletion, we discovered at the deletion junction a 13-bp sequence (5' . Factor IX Seattle 1 is a rare intragenic deletion associated with hemophilia B. In this study, we investigated the mechanism behind the gene deletion by analyzing the sequence at the deletion junction. Surprisingly, we identified a 13-bp sequence that was identical at both ends of the deletion. This finding suggests that recombination between two 14-bp homologous sequences resulted in the deletion of a 10-kb segment of the factor IX gene. This mechanism of gene deletion has important implications for understanding the molecular basis of genetic disorders and underscores the need for careful examination of the sequence surrounding gene deletions. Further studies are warranted to investigate the prevalence and significance of similar recombination events in other genetic diseases.

Pleuropulmonary manifestations of hepatic amebiasis Pleuropulmonary manifestations of hepatic amebiasis occurred in 30 patients; 18 (60%) presented with at least 1 pulmonary complaint and 10 (33%) had multiple pulmonary symptoms. In patients with hepatic amebiasis, pleuropulmonary manifestations were observed in 30 individuals. Among these, 60% presented with at least one pulmonary complaint, while 33% experienced multiple pulmonary symptoms. Common manifestations included cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Radiographic findings revealed pleural effusion, consolidation, and nodules. The presence of pleural effusion was significantly associated with the development of severe hepatic amebiasis. Chest imaging, including ultrasound and computed tomography, proved valuable in diagnosing pleuropulmonary involvement. Prompt recognition and appropriate management of these pleuropulmonary manifestations are crucial to ensure optimal patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the development of these pulmonary complications in hepatic amebiasis.

The presence of human papillomavirus (HPV) in solitary adult laryngeal papillomas demonstrated by in-situ DNA hybridization with sulphonated probes. In-situ DNA hybridization with sulphonated probes was used to detect the presence of human papillomavirus (HPV) in solitary adult laryngeal papillomas. Of the 24 papillomas examined, HPV DNA sequences were detected in 19 cases (79%). The most common types of HPV identified were types 6 and 11, detected in 14 cases and 3 cases, respectively. In addition, HPV types 16 and 18 were detected in one case each. These findings indicate a high prevalence of HPV involvement in solitary adult laryngeal papillomas. The identification of HPV in these cases suggests a potential role of this virus in the pathogenesis of the disease. Further studies are warranted to investigate the clinical implications of HPV detection and to explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting HPV in laryngeal papillomas.

Serological evidence of infection with Helicobacter pylori may predict gastrointestinal intolerance to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) treatment in rheumatoid arthritis. In this study, the authors investigated the association between serological evidence of Helicobacter pylori infection and gastrointestinal intolerance to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) treatment in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. A total of 120 patients with rheumatoid arthritis were enrolled, and serological testing for H. pylori was performed. Gastrointestinal intolerance to NSAID treatment was assessed using a validated questionnaire. The results showed that 40% of the patients had serological evidence of H. pylori infection, and 60% reported gastrointestinal intolerance to NSAIDs. Importantly, patients with serological evidence of H. pylori infection were significantly more likely to experience gastrointestinal intolerance to NSAID treatment compared to those without H. pylori infection (p<0.05). These findings suggest that serological evidence of H. pylori infection may be a predictive marker for gastrointestinal intolerance to NSAID treatment in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Further research is needed to confirm and understand the underlying mechanisms of this association.

Polyamine levels in healthy and tumor tissues of patients with colon adenocarcinoma. Colorectal cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer-related deaths worldwide. The dysregulation of polyamine metabolism has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several cancers, including colon adenocarcinoma. This study aimed to evaluate the levels of polyamines, including putrescine, spermidine, and spermine, in both healthy and tumor tissues of patients with colon adenocarcinoma. The authors collected tissue samples from 30 patients undergoing surgical resection for colon adenocarcinoma and assessed polyamine levels using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed significantly higher levels of putrescine, spermidine, and spermine in tumor tissues compared to healthy tissues. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between tumor stage and polyamine levels, indicating a potential role of polyamines as prognostic markers for colon adenocarcinoma. These findings highlight the importance of polyamine metabolism in colon cancer progression and may provide insight into the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.

HLA class I and class II antigen expression on squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck. The expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class I and class II antigens on squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the head and neck plays a crucial role in the antitumor immune response. This study aimed to investigate the expression of these antigens in SCC patients. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on tumor samples obtained from 60 patients with SCC of the head and neck. The expression levels of HLA class I and class II antigens were quantitatively analyzed and compared with clinicopathological features. Our results showed that HLA class I antigens were expressed in 82% of SCC samples, while HLA class II antigens were expressed in 62% of samples. Higher HLA class I expression was significantly associated with better overall survival and disease-free survival rates. Additionally, increased HLA class II expression was correlated with lymph node metastasis and advanced tumor stage. These findings suggest that HLA class I and class II antigen expression may serve as prognostic markers and potential targets for immunotherapeutic interventions in SCC of the head and neck.

Denervation in hemiplegic muscles. Hemiplegia, characterized by paralysis of one side of the body, often leads to muscle denervation and subsequent atrophy. This study aimed to investigate the effects of denervation in hemiplegic muscles in 25 patients with hemiplegia. Muscle denervation was induced by selective neurectomy in 13 patients, while the remaining 12 served as controls. The outcomes were evaluated based on muscle strength, electromyographic activity, and muscle diameter. 

The results showed that denervation in hemiplegic muscles resulted in a significant decrease in muscle strength compared to the control group. Electromyographic activity also decreased in the denervated muscles, indicating reduced neuromuscular function. Furthermore, muscle diameter was significantly reduced in the denervated muscles, demonstrating muscle atrophy. 

Patients who underwent neurectomy experienced complications such as wound infection and delayed healing in 4 cases. Despite these complications, the majority of patients reported improvements in muscle strength and function following neurectomy. 

In conclusion, denervation in hemiplegic muscles leads to muscle weakness, reduced neuromuscular function, and muscle atrophy. Neurectomy showed promising results in improving muscle strength and function, albeit with some associated complications. Further studies are necessary to explore the long-term effects and potential benefits of neurectomy in hemiplegic patients.

Systemic hypertension in sleep apnea syndrome. Review article. Systemic hypertension is a common comorbidity in patients with sleep apnea syndrome (SAS). This review aims to summarize the current evidence regarding the relationship between SAS and systemic hypertension. Multiple studies have shown a strong association between SAS and hypertension, with some suggesting a dose-response relationship. The pathophysiology of this association is believed to involve intermittent hypoxia, sympathetic activation, endothelial dysfunction, and increased oxidative stress. Treatment of SAS with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy has been shown to significantly reduce blood pressure levels in hypertensive patients. However, adherence to CPAP therapy remains a challenge. Further research is needed to develop innovative strategies to improve adherence and optimize outcomes in patients with SAS and hypertension.

Nucleolar organizer regions in precancerous and cancerous lesions of the bronchus.  Using a silver staining technique, nucleolar organizer region-associated proteins (Ag-NOR) were studied in paraffin sections of five specimens of normal bronchial epithelium, eight of atypical squamous metaplasia, five of carcinoma in situ, and seven of microinvasive squamous cell carcinoma.  The mean number of Ag-NOR in the nucleus were normal epithelium 1. In this study, the presence of nucleolar organizer regions (NOR) in different stages of bronchial lesions was investigated using a silver staining technique. The study included specimens of normal bronchial epithelium, atypical squamous metaplasia, carcinoma in situ, and microinvasive squamous cell carcinoma. The results showed a progressive increase in the mean number of Ag-NOR in the nucleus from normal epithelium to microinvasive squamous cell carcinoma. This suggests that the accumulation of Ag-NOR may be associated with the development and progression of bronchial lesions, indicating their potential use as a marker for the early detection and monitoring of bronchial cancer. Further research is needed to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms.

Development of language in six hemispherectomized patients. This study aimed to investigate the development of language in six patients who underwent hemispherectomy. The participants were children who had undergone the surgical removal of one cerebral hemisphere to treat severe epilepsy. Language skills were assessed using standardized tests and compared to matched controls. Results showed that all hemispherectomized patients demonstrated significant language development, with most achieving age-appropriate language skills. However, there were individual differences in language outcomes, with some patients showing better performance in expressive language skills compared to receptive language skills, and vice versa. The findings suggest that hemispherectomy does not necessarily result in severe language deficits and that the remaining hemisphere can compensate for the lost language functions. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying language recovery in hemispherectomized patients and to optimize rehabilitation strategies for this population.

Prevalence of common and dysplastic naevi in a Swedish population.  The naevus profile was examined in a Swedish population that was randomly selected from a census file. The prevalence of common and dysplastic naevi in a Swedish population was investigated. A total of 1,500 individuals, randomly selected from a census file, were included in the study. The participants underwent a thorough examination of their naevus profile, including counting and mapping of naevi. The results showed that the prevalence of common naevi was 75%, with an average of 20.3 naevi per person. Dysplastic naevi were found in 12% of the population, with an average of 1.5 dysplastic naevi per person. There was a significant correlation between the presence of dysplastic naevi and a family history of melanoma. Additionally, participants with dysplastic naevi were more likely to have a larger number of common naevi. These findings provide important information regarding the prevalence and characteristics of naevi in the Swedish population, which may contribute to the development of targeted screening and prevention strategies for melanoma.

Effects of anticonvulsant treatment and low levels of folate and thiamine on amine metabolites in cerebrospinal fluid. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of anticonvulsant treatment and low levels of folate and thiamine on amine metabolites in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). CSF samples were obtained from patients with epilepsy who were either receiving anticonvulsant treatment or were untreated, and from healthy controls. The levels of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin metabolites were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed that patients receiving anticonvulsant treatment had significantly lower levels of dopamine and norepinephrine metabolites compared to untreated patients and controls. However, there were no significant differences in serotonin metabolite levels between the three groups. Furthermore, patients with low levels of folate and thiamine showed significantly lower levels of dopamine and norepinephrine metabolites compared to patients with normal levels of these vitamins. These findings suggest that anticonvulsant treatment and low levels of folate and thiamine may alter amine metabolism in the central nervous system, which could have implications for the management of epilepsy and the potential development of neuropsychiatric symptoms in these patients.

Management of mycotic rupture of the ascending aorta after heart-lung transplantation.  A 19-year-old woman underwent heart-lung transplantation for obstructive bronchiolitis. Mycotic rupture of the ascending aorta is a rare but fatal complication following heart-lung transplantation. This case report presents the management of a 19-year-old woman who developed mycotic rupture of the ascending aorta after undergoing the transplantation procedure for obstructive bronchiolitis. The patient initially presented with fever and sepsis, and imaging studies revealed a pseudoaneurysm in the ascending aorta with associated surrounding abscess formation. An emergency surgical intervention was performed, involving debridement of the infected tissue, reconstruction of the ascending aorta with a prosthetic graft, and antibiotic therapy. Follow-up imaging showed a successful repair of the aortic rupture, without any evidence of residual abscess or graft infection. The patient's clinical condition improved, and she was discharged in stable condition on a long-term antibiotic regimen. This case underscores the importance of prompt recognition and aggressive surgical management of mycotic rupture of the ascending aorta in post-transplant patients to achieve favorable outcomes.

Degenerative aortic stenosis. Degenerative aortic stenosis (DAS) is a common cardiac valvular disorder characterized by progressive narrowing of the aortic valve orifice due to calcification and fibrosis. This review aims to provide an overview of the pathophysiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, and management of DAS. The primary etiology of DAS is atherosclerosis, which leads to a chronic inflammatory response, oxidative stress, and activation of matrix metalloproteinases, ultimately resulting in valve calcification and dysfunction. Risk factors for DAS include age, male gender, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and genetic predisposition. Clinical features of DAS can range from asymptomatic to exertional dyspnea, angina, and syncope. The diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, and treatment options include medical therapy, aortic valve replacement, or transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI). Management strategies should be tailored based on patient age, comorbidities, and severity of symptoms. Close monitoring and appropriate intervention are necessary to improve outcomes and quality of life in patients with DAS.

Perianal appearances associated with constipation.  The perianal appearances were studied prospectively of 136 constipated children (mean age 3. The aim of this study was to investigate the perianal appearances associated with constipation in children. A total of 136 constipated children with a mean age of 3 years were included in the study. Perianal appearances were assessed prospectively using standardized criteria. The majority of children (91.9%) exhibited abnormalities in perianal appearances, with the most common findings being perianal erythema (80.9%) and anal fissures (65.4%). Other findings included skin tags (38.2%), perianal excoriation (30.9%), and perianal rash (23.5%). The presence of perianal fissures was significantly associated with severe constipation (p < 0.05). Furthermore, children with perianal erythema were more likely to have a history of hard stools (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that perianal appearances can serve as important indicators of constipation in children. Early identification of these abnormalities may lead to timely interventions and improved management of constipation in pediatric populations. Further studies are warranted to better understand the relationship between perianal appearances and constipation severity.

Delayed positive gastrointestinal bleeding studies with technetium-99m-red blood cells: utility of a second injection. Delayed positive gastrointestinal bleeding studies using technetium-99m-labeled red blood cells (RBCs) have been a valuable diagnostic tool in the evaluation of patients with suspected GI bleeding. However, in certain cases, the initial injection of radiolabeled RBCs may fail to detect the bleeding site due to low sensitivity or inadequate uptake. In this study, we investigated the utility of a second injection of technetium-99m-labeled RBCs in detecting delayed positive bleeding in patients who initially had negative or inconclusive results. Our results showed that a second injection of radiolabeled RBCs significantly improved the detection of delayed positive bleeding, leading to more accurate localization of the bleeding site. Furthermore, the use of additional imaging modalities, such as single-photon emission computed tomography, further enhanced the sensitivity and specificity of the diagnostic procedure. Ultimately, the incorporation of a second injection of radiolabeled RBCs and advanced imaging techniques can improve the diagnostic accuracy and management decisions in patients with delayed positive gastrointestinal bleeding.

Performing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy using colonoscopes: experience in 500 subjects. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a commonly used screening tool for colorectal cancer, as it allows for direct visualization of the distal sigmoid colon and rectum. However, the use of colonoscopes for performing sigmoidoscopy has gained attention due to its potential advantages over traditional sigmoidoscopes. In this study, we present our experience with performing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy using colonoscopes in 500 subjects. The procedure was well-tolerated by the patients and yielded high-quality images of the sigmoid colon and rectum. Polyps were detected in a significant proportion of subjects, highlighting the importance of this screening modality in identifying early precancerous lesions. We also discuss the technical aspects and potential benefits of using colonoscopes for sigmoidoscopy, including improved maneuverability and visualization. Overall, our findings support the use of colonoscopes for performing screening flexible sigmoidoscopy, offering a promising approach for colorectal cancer prevention and early detection.

Hashimoto's encephalopathy: a steroid-responsive disorder associated with high anti-thyroid antibody titers--report of 5 cases. Hashimoto's encephalopathy is a rare neurological disorder characterized by acute or subacute encephalopathy in patients with high titers of anti-thyroid antibodies. This report presents a case series of five patients diagnosed with Hashimoto's encephalopathy and treated with steroids. The patients' clinical presentations varied, with symptoms such as confusion, seizures, psychosis, and stroke-like episodes. All patients had markedly elevated anti-thyroid antibody titers, supporting the diagnosis of Hashimoto's encephalopathy. Treatment with high-dose intravenous steroids resulted in rapid improvement of symptoms and normalization of cognitive function in all cases. Recurrences of symptoms were observed in two patients who had incomplete maintenance steroid tapering. These cases highlight the importance of recognizing Hashimoto's encephalopathy as a potential cause of encephalopathy and emphasize the need for early diagnosis and prompt treatment with steroids to achieve favorable outcomes. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this rare and underdiagnosed disorder.

The gonadotropin-releasing hormone associated peptide reduces calcium entry in prolactin-secreting cells. The gonadotropin-releasing hormone associated peptide (GnRHAP) has been shown to play a role in regulating calcium entry in various cell types. In this study, we investigated the effect of GnRHAP on calcium entry in prolactin-secreting cells. Our results demonstrate that GnRHAP significantly reduces calcium entry in these cells, suggesting a potential inhibitory role of GnRHAP in prolactin secretion. Furthermore, we found that this effect is mediated by the activation of G protein-coupled receptors and subsequent inhibition of voltage-gated calcium channels. These findings provide further insights into the regulatory mechanisms of prolactin secretion and highlight the potential therapeutic implications of targeting GnRHAP signaling in conditions associated with abnormal prolactin levels.

The role of endoscopic injection sclerotherapy in the management of bleeding peristomal varices. Peristomal varices are a well-known complication in patients with portal hypertension and liver cirrhosis. Although rare, bleeding from peristomal varices can be life-threatening and challenging to manage. We present a case of a 54-year-old male with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis and an ileostomy who presented with recurrent episodes of peristomal variceal bleeding. Despite multiple conservative measures, including endoscopic band ligation, the patient continued to experience hemorrhagic episodes. Given the persistent bleeding, we opted for endoscopic injection sclerotherapy (EIS) using a combination of ethanolamine oleate and sodium tetradecyl sulfate. EIS successfully achieved hemostasis, and the patient remained free from bleeding during the six-month follow-up period. This case highlights the potential efficacy of EIS in the management of bleeding peristomal varices. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and the role of EIS as a first-line treatment option in this population.

Multiple-pulse stimulation and dantrolene in malignant hyperthermia. Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of using multiple-pulse stimulation (MPS) and dantrolene in managing MH episodes. A total of 47 patients diagnosed with MH were included in the study. All patients received treatment with dantrolene, while 24 patients additionally received MPS. The main outcome measures assessed were the time to resolution of signs and symptoms, occurrence of adverse events, and patient outcomes. The results showed that the combination of dantrolene and MPS significantly reduced the time to resolution of MH symptoms compared to dantrolene alone (p<0.05). Additionally, no significant adverse events were reported in the MPS group. The overall patient outcomes were favorable, with no mortalities reported. These findings suggest that the use of MPS in conjunction with dantrolene may be a beneficial approach in the management of MH, resulting in faster resolution of symptoms and improved patient outcomes. Further investigation is warranted to optimize the use of MPS in MH treatment protocols.

Stroke rehabilitation: a geropsychological perspective. Stroke rehabilitation is a crucial aspect of geriatric care, as strokes are prevalent among older adults and can lead to significant functional impairments. This literature review provides a geropsychological perspective on stroke rehabilitation, focusing on the psychological factors that influence recovery and outcomes in older stroke survivors. The review explores the impact of cognitive function, emotional well-being, and social support on post-stroke rehabilitation. Additionally, it examines the role of interdisciplinary interventions, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy and psychosocial interventions, in improving stroke rehabilitation outcomes. The findings highlight the importance of comprehensive psychological assessments and tailored interventions to address the unique needs of older stroke survivors during rehabilitation. Further research is needed to develop evidence-based guidelines for geropsychological interventions in stroke rehabilitation.

Surgical management of oculomotor nerve palsy We treated seven patients with unilateral oculomotor nerve palsy by transposition of the insertion of the superior oblique tendon to a point anterior and medial to the insertion of the superior rectus muscle without trochleotomy (Scott procedure). This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of transposition of the superior oblique tendon in the surgical management of unilateral oculomotor nerve palsy. Seven patients with this condition underwent the Scott procedure, which involved repositioning the superior oblique tendon to a specific point anterior and medial to the insertion of the superior rectus muscle, without trochleotomy. After the surgery, all patients experienced significant improvement in their ocular motility, with resolution of the oculomotor nerve palsy. This procedure appears to be a viable surgical option for the treatment of unilateral oculomotor nerve palsy. Further studies with larger samples are warranted to confirm these findings.

Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass after failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. Deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass surgery is a viable option for patients who have undergone failed femoropopliteal reconstructions. This procedure is performed to restore blood flow to the lower extremities in patients with peripheral arterial disease. The success of the bypass relies on proper patient selection and surgical technique. The graft is typically taken from the autogenous deep femoral artery and anastomosed to the anterior tibial artery. This procedure has shown promising results in improving limb salvage rates and relieving symptoms associated with lower extremity ischemia. However, careful preoperative evaluation and postoperative surveillance are necessary to identify any complications and ensure optimal outcomes for patients undergoing deep femoral to anterior tibial bypass.

Closure of refractory perineal Crohn's lesion. Perineal lesions in Crohn's disease pose a challenge in terms of treatment and management. We present a case of a refractory perineal Crohn's lesion that was successfully closed using a combination of surgical, medical, and wound care strategies. The patient, a 42-year-old male, had a history of Crohn's disease with perianal involvement. Despite undergoing multiple surgical interventions and receiving various medical treatments, the perineal lesion refrained from healing. Finally, a tailored treatment plan was devised, consisting of wide local excision, complex flap reconstruction, and a comprehensive wound care regimen. Over the course of several months, the perineal lesion showed significant improvement, with complete closure achieved. This case highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and individualized treatment strategies for refractory perineal Crohn's lesions. Further studies are warranted to establish optimal management protocols for such challenging cases.

Rehabilitation of three patients after treatment for herpes encephalitis. Herpes encephalitis is a serious neurological complication caused by the herpes simplex virus. While antiviral agents have improved the prognosis of this condition, there is limited literature on the rehabilitation outcomes of patients following treatment. In this case series, we present the rehabilitation progress of three patients who underwent intensive rehabilitation following their recovery from herpes encephalitis. All patients demonstrated significant cognitive, motor, and functional deficits during initial assessments. A multidisciplinary rehabilitation program was implemented, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy. Over the course of several months, all three patients showed improvements in cognitive functions, motor skills, and activities of daily living. Overall, our findings suggest that comprehensive rehabilitation interventions can lead to favorable recovery outcomes in patients with herpes encephalitis. Further research is needed to explore optimal timing and duration of rehabilitation interventions in this population.

Deletion of Alu sequences in the fifth c-sis intron in individuals with meningiomas. Meningiomas are primary tumors of the central nervous system that arise from the meninges. The development of these tumors is thought to be influenced by genetic factors. In a recent study, researchers investigated the presence of Alu sequences in the fifth c-sis intron in individuals with meningiomas. Alu sequences are repetitive elements found within the human genome that have been associated with various diseases. The study found that individuals with meningiomas had a higher frequency of Alu sequence deletions in the fifth c-sis intron compared to healthy controls. These findings suggest that the presence of Alu sequence deletions in this intron may be a potential risk factor for the development of meningiomas. Further research is needed to fully understand the role of Alu sequences in meningioma pathogenesis.

A double-blind study of deflazacort and prednisone in patients with chronic inflammatory disorders. Chronic inflammatory disorders are characterized by persistent inflammation, which can lead to tissue damage and long-term complications. Glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are commonly used to suppress inflammation and alleviate symptoms. However, these medications are associated with multiple side effects. Deflazacort, a newer synthetic glucocorticoid, has been proposed as an alternative with potentially fewer adverse effects. 

In this double-blind study, patients with chronic inflammatory disorders were randomized to receive either deflazacort or prednisone for a predetermined duration. The primary outcome measure was the improvement in disease activity, as assessed by validated scoring systems. Secondary outcomes included the occurrence of adverse events and changes in laboratory parameters.

Preliminary results showed comparable efficacy between deflazacort and prednisone in controlling disease activity. However, the incidence of adverse events was significantly lower in the deflazacort group, particularly in terms of glucose intolerance and weight gain. These findings suggest that deflazacort may offer a safer alternative to prednisone in the management of chronic inflammatory disorders. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to confirm these results.

Angiography, angioscopy, and ultrasound imaging before and after percutaneous balloon angioplasty. We evaluated the efficacy of percutaneous balloon angioplasty (PBA) in the treatment of peripheral vascular diseases by assessing the changes in angiography, angioscopy, and ultrasound imaging before and after the procedure. A total of 50 patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) were enrolled in this study. Angiography revealed significant stenosis or occlusion in the affected arteries. Angioscopy provided direct visualization of the affected vessels, confirming the presence of plaque and thrombus. Ultrasound imaging demonstrated reduced blood flow velocity and turbulence in the affected arteries. Following PBA, angiography revealed improved blood flow and patency of the treated vessels. Angioscopy showed removal or dislodgement of plaque and thrombus, with enhanced vascular luminal diameter. Ultrasound imaging demonstrated improved blood flow velocity and reduced turbulence. These findings suggest that PBA is an effective treatment option for peripheral vascular diseases, resulting in improved blood flow and vascular patency, as confirmed by angiography, angioscopy, and ultrasound imaging. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and durability of PBA in the management of PAD.

A successful treatment of an intrarenal arteriovenous fistula by percutaneous embolization. Intrarenal arteriovenous fistulas (AVFs) are rare but potentially serious vascular anomalies that can cause significant morbidity if left untreated. We present a case of a 42-year-old female with a symptomatic intrarenal AVF, which was successfully treated with percutaneous embolization. The patient presented with gross hematuria and flank pain and was found to have an enlarged and tortuous renal artery on imaging. Angiography confirmed the presence of an intrarenal AVF connecting a branch of the renal artery to a renal vein. Under fluoroscopic guidance, embolization material was selectively delivered to the site of the AVF, leading to complete occlusion and resolution of symptoms. Follow-up imaging at 3 months demonstrated no residual AVF and preserved renal function. Percutaneous embolization is a safe and effective treatment option for intrarenal AVFs, offering a minimally invasive alternative to surgical intervention.

The influence of calcium alginate haemostatic swabs upon operative blood loss in adenotonsillectomy.  Although adenotonsillectomy is regarded as a minor procedure, it has been shown that 18% of patients may experience an operative blood loss of 10-20% of the total blood volume. To evaluate the influence of calcium alginate haemostatic swabs on operative blood loss in adenotonsillectomy, a randomized controlled trial was conducted. Forty patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy were randomly assigned to receive either calcium alginate haemostatic swabs or standard surgical swabs during the procedure. Operative blood loss was measured and compared between the two groups. The results showed that the use of calcium alginate haemostatic swabs significantly reduced operative blood loss compared to standard surgical swabs (mean difference 12.5 ml, p<0.001). Furthermore, there was no significant difference in postoperative complications between the two groups. Therefore, the use of calcium alginate haemostatic swabs can be considered a safe and effective method for reducing operative blood loss in adenotonsillectomy. Further studies are needed to validate these findings.

Reversal of chronic hepatic encephalopathy by colonic exclusion: poor correlation with blood GABA levels. Colonic exclusion has been suggested as a potential treatment for chronic hepatic encephalopathy (CHE). The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between colonic exclusion and blood gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) levels in patients with CHE. Seven patients with CHE who underwent colonic exclusion were included in the study. Blood samples were collected before and after the procedure, and GABA levels were measured using a spectrophotometric assay. Clinical improvement was assessed using the West Haven criteria. Our results showed that colonic exclusion led to a significant improvement in clinical symptoms in all patients. However, there was no significant correlation between blood GABA levels and clinical improvement. These findings suggest that the mechanism by which colonic exclusion reverses CHE may not be solely related to GABA metabolism and that other factors may be involved. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

Dietary fat and risk of breast cancer.  The relationship between dietary fat and subsequent risk of breast cancer was studied in 3988 initially cancer-free Finnish women aged 20-69 y.  During a follow-up period of 20 y, 54 breast-cancer cases were diagnosed.  Risk of breast cancer was significantly inversely related to energy intake and nonsignificantly inversely related to absolute fat intake.  A positive association between energy-adjusted total fat intake and occurrence of breast cancer was also observed. This study examined the association between dietary fat intake and the risk of breast cancer in 3988 Finnish women aged 20-69 years. Over a 20-year follow-up period, 54 cases of breast cancer were identified. The results showed a significant inverse relationship between energy intake and risk of breast cancer, suggesting that higher energy intake may be protective against breast cancer development. However, the association between absolute fat intake and breast cancer risk was not statistically significant. Interestingly, when total fat intake was adjusted for energy intake, a positive association with breast cancer occurrence was observed. These findings highlight the complex relationship between dietary fat and breast cancer risk and indicate the need for further research in this area.

Reinforcement of incontinent stools in the treatment of encopresis. Encopresis, the voluntary or involuntary passage of feces in inappropriate places by a child who should have achieved bowel control, is a distressing condition for both the child and the family. Reinforcement of incontinent stools is a treatment approach that involves the use of techniques such as positive reinforcement and scheduled toilet sitting to promote regular and complete bowel movements in children with encopresis. This abstract highlights the importance of reinforcement in the management of encopresis and emphasizes the need for further research to explore the effectiveness of different reinforcement strategies and their long-term outcomes.

Background review and current concepts of reperfusion injury. Reperfusion injury is a complex pathophysiological process that occurs following the restoration of blood flow to ischemic tissue. It is characterized by the exacerbation of tissue damage and dysfunction, which can occur in multiple organ systems. Although reperfusion is essential for tissue survival, the restoration of blood flow can paradoxically lead to the production of reactive oxygen species, cytokine release, and activation of inflammatory pathways. These events can further damage the ischemic tissue and contribute to the development of organ dysfunction. This review aims to provide an overview of the current understanding of reperfusion injury, including its underlying mechanisms, diagnostic approaches, and potential therapeutic strategies. The identification of novel therapeutic targets may have significant implications in preventing and mitigating the impact of reperfusion injury in clinical settings.

Infantile CNS spongy degeneration--14 cases: clinical update. Infantile central nervous system (CNS) spongy degeneration is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive neurological deterioration. We provide a clinical update on 14 cases of this condition. The patients, aged 3 months to 6 years at presentation, exhibited various clinical features including delayed development, regression, hypotonia, and seizures. Neuroimaging showed characteristic spongy changes in the cerebral white matter. Biochemical analysis revealed deficient activity of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A. Molecular genetic testing identified pathogenic mutations in the ARSA gene in all cases. Symptomatic treatment with antiepileptic drugs and supportive care were provided, but disease progression was relentless. The natural history and clinical variability of infantile CNS spongy degeneration underscore the importance of early diagnosis and genetic counseling for affected families.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is a rare condition characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the auricle. The etiology of this condition is uncertain, but it is believed to result from trauma or repetitive pressure on the ear. This abstract presents a case of pseudocyst of the auricle successfully treated with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid (TCA) injection and button bolsters. A 26-year-old male patient presented with a painful swelling in his right ear. Clinical examination and imaging confirmed the diagnosis of pseudocyst of the auricle. Following a failed aspiration attempt, the patient underwent treatment with intracartilaginous TCA injection and button bolsters. A satisfactory outcome was achieved, with complete resolution of the pseudocyst and symptom improvement. This case highlights the efficacy of this minimally invasive treatment approach for pseudocyst of the auricle.

Use of the fistula assessment monitor to detect stenoses in access fistulae. The use of the Fistula Assessment Monitor (FAM) to detect stenoses in access fistulae has been gaining attention in recent years. Stenosis, a narrowing of the blood vessels, is a common and significant complication in patients with arteriovenous fistulae used for hemodialysis. Early detection and timely intervention are crucial to prevent access dysfunction and maintain hemodialysis adequacy. The FAM is a non-invasive, easy-to-use device that utilizes radiofrequency-based technology to measure blood flow and detect changes in access fistula function. Several studies have reported the effectiveness of FAM in detecting stenoses, with high sensitivity and specificity. Moreover, the use of FAM has also been associated with improved outcomes, including decreased hospital admissions and increased fistula longevity. In conclusion, the FAM is a valuable tool for monitoring access fistulae and detecting stenoses, leading to more efficient management and improved outcomes in hemodialysis patients.

Reversal of chronic hepatic encephalopathy by colonic exclusion: poor correlation with blood GABA levels. Chronic hepatic encephalopathy (HE) is a debilitating condition associated with liver dysfunction. Colonic exclusion, a surgical procedure that diverts the fecal stream from the colon, has shown promise in reversing hepatic encephalopathy. However, the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This study aimed to investigate the role of blood gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) levels, a neurotransmitter implicated in HE, in the efficacy of colonic exclusion in treating chronic HE. A retrospective analysis of 25 patients who underwent colonic exclusion for chronic HE was performed. Improvement in neurological symptoms was observed in 80% of the patients. Surprisingly, there was no significant correlation between blood GABA levels and clinical improvement following colonic exclusion. These findings suggest that the beneficial effects of colonic exclusion in reversing chronic HE may not be mediated solely by alterations in blood GABA levels. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic effects of colonic exclusion on HE.

Serial neurobehavioral assessments in preterm infants. The neurodevelopmental outcome of preterm infants is of great concern due to their increased risk for cognitive and motor deficits. Serial neurobehavioral assessments are essential to monitor the progress and identify early signs of potential neurodevelopmental impairments. This study aimed to investigate the utility of serial neurobehavioral assessments in preterm infants during their neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) stay. A comprehensive literature search was conducted, and studies assessing the neurobehavioral outcomes of preterm infants using serial assessments were reviewed. Findings suggest that serial neurobehavioral assessments provide valuable information on the neurodevelopmental trajectory of preterm infants, enabling early identification of developmental delays and initiation of appropriate interventions. Additionally, these assessments can guide the adjustment of therapeutic strategies, monitor treatment response, and inform decisions regarding discharge planning. Further research is needed to establish standardized protocols for serial neurobehavioral assessments in preterm infants, allowing for consistent monitoring and enhanced neurodevelopmental outcomes in this vulnerable population.

Endothelial cell adhesiveness for human T lymphocytes is inhibited by transforming growth factor-beta 1. Transforming growth factor-beta 1 (TGF-beta 1) plays a crucial role in modulating immune responses, including the adhesion of T lymphocytes to endothelial cells. To investigate the effect of TGF-beta 1 on endothelial cell adhesiveness for T lymphocytes, an in vitro study was conducted. Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were cultured and pretreated with various concentrations of TGF-beta 1. T lymphocytes were then labeled with a fluorescent dye and allowed to adhere to the HUVECs. The results demonstrated that TGF-beta 1 significantly inhibited the adhesion of T lymphocytes to HUVECs in a dose-dependent manner. Furthermore, Western blot analysis revealed a decrease in the expression of adhesion molecules, such as intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1), on the surface of HUVECs after TGF-beta 1 treatment. These findings suggest that TGF-beta 1 can suppress the adhesiveness of endothelial cells for T lymphocytes, providing potential therapeutic implications for diseases involving aberrant T cell migration and adhesion. Further studies are warranted to fully elucidate the underlying mechanisms of this inhibitory effect.

Discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs in children who have outgrown epilepsy: effects on cognitive function. Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) are commonly used to manage epilepsy in children. However, the long-term effects of AEDs on cognitive function, especially after seizure remission, remain unclear. This study aimed to investigate the cognitive outcomes in children who discontinued AEDs after outgrowing epilepsy. A comprehensive neuropsychological battery was administered to 50 children who had been seizure-free for at least two years and were no longer taking AEDs. Results revealed that discontinuation of AEDs did not significantly impact global cognitive functioning, processing speed, or attention. However, subtle declines were observed in verbal memory and executive functioning. These findings suggest that cautious consideration and monitoring are needed when discontinuing AEDs in children who have outgrown epilepsy to ensure optimal cognitive outcomes.

Tables for estimation of individual risks of fetal neural tube and ventral wall defects, incorporating prior probability, maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein levels, and ultrasonographic examination results. Prenatal screening for fetal neural tube and ventral wall defects is crucial for early diagnosis and appropriate management. Currently, the estimation of individual risks relies on a combination of factors, including prior probability, maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels, and ultrasonographic examination results. In this study, we aimed to develop tables that incorporate these factors to improve the accuracy of risk assessment. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of pregnant women who underwent prenatal screening for these defects. The tables were constructed using statistical modeling techniques, taking into account the individual probabilities of each factor. Validation of the tables was performed using a separate cohort of pregnant women. 

The results showed that the developed tables provided a reliable estimation of individual risks, with high sensitivity and specificity. By incorporating MSAFP levels and ultrasonographic examination results, the tables allowed for more precise risk stratification and improved clinical decision-making. Overall, these tables have the potential to enhance prenatal screening programs and improve outcomes for infants at risk of neural tube and ventral wall defects.

Spinal coning after lumbar puncture in prostate cancer with asymptomatic vertebral metastasis: a case report.  A 60-year-old man was admitted to our hospital for complete urinary retention. During evaluation for the cause of his urinary retention, the patient underwent a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. Shortly after the procedure, he developed severe back pain and bilateral lower extremity weakness. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine revealed multiple osteoblastic metastases involving the lumbar vertebrae. However, no evidence of cord compression or epidural metastasis was observed. Subsequent MRI demonstrated significant spinal cord edema and distortion, consistent with spinal coning. The patient was promptly treated with corticosteroids and underwent radiotherapy for palliation. This case highlights the importance of cautious evaluation and management in patients with known or suspected spinal metastases, as lumbar puncture can potentially precipitate spinal coning and neurological compromise even in the absence of obvious epidural compression.

Left atrial to femoral arterial bypass using the biomedicus pump for operations of the thoracic aorta. Left atrial to femoral arterial bypass (LA-FAB) has been increasingly utilized as a method of providing distal perfusion during thoracic aortic surgery. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes and feasibility of LA-FAB using the Biomedicus pump for thoracic aortic operations. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 68 patients who underwent LA-FAB with the Biomedicus pump at a single institution over a five-year period. The primary outcomes evaluated were mortality, neurologic complications, duration of bypass, and postoperative complications. The overall mortality rate was 4.4%, with no neurologic complications reported. The mean duration of bypass was 122 minutes. Postoperative complications included respiratory failure (10.3%), renal dysfunction (7.4%), and bleeding requiring reoperation (4.4%). The use of LA-FAB with the Biomedicus pump was found to be a safe and effective technique for providing distal perfusion during complex thoracic aortic surgeries. Further studies are warranted to explore its potential benefits and limitations compared to alternative techniques.

Acute deterioration of renal function associated with enteric hyperoxaluria. Enteric hyperoxaluria is a rare condition characterized by increased absorption of oxalate from the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in elevated urinary oxalate levels. Acute deterioration of renal function is a potential complication of enteric hyperoxaluria, but there have been limited reports on this association. We present the case of a 54-year-old man with a history of Crohn's disease who presented with acute kidney injury. Initial workup revealed elevated urinary oxalate levels and subsequent investigation confirmed the diagnosis of enteric hyperoxaluria. The patient underwent treatment with aggressive hydration, restriction of dietary oxalate, and pharmacological intervention including oral calcium supplementation and potassium citrate. Renal function improved gradually with these interventions. This case highlights the importance of considering enteric hyperoxaluria in the differential diagnosis of acute kidney injury, particularly in patients with underlying gastrointestinal conditions. Early recognition and prompt management can potentially prevent further renal damage and improve long-term outcomes in these patients. Large-scale studies are warranted to better understand the relationship between enteric hyperoxaluria and acute renal failure.

Experience with esmolol for the treatment of cocaine-associated cardiovascular complications. Cocaine use frequently results in cardiovascular complications, including myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and hypertension. Esmolol, a short-acting β1-selective adrenergic receptor antagonist, has been proposed as a potential treatment option for these complications due to its ability to rapidly decrease heart rate and blood pressure. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of esmolol in the management of cocaine-associated cardiovascular complications. A retrospective analysis of patients treated with esmolol for cocaine-related cardiovascular events was conducted. The results demonstrated that esmolol effectively controlled heart rate and blood pressure in the majority of patients. Additionally, no significant adverse events were reported. These findings suggest that esmolol may be a valuable therapeutic option for managing cocaine-induced cardiovascular complications.

Prospective randomized comparison of Brown-McHardy and microvasive balloon dilators in treatment of achalasia.  We report the results of a randomized prospective study comparing a standard bougie rubber balloon dilator [Brown-McHardy (BMH)] and a newer polyethylene dilator passed over a guide wire [Microvasive Rigiflex (MVR)]. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of two different dilators, Brown-McHardy (BMH) and Microvasive Rigiflex (MVR), in the treatment of achalasia. A total of 50 patients with achalasia were randomly assigned to undergo either BMH dilatation or MVR dilatation. The primary outcome measures included improvement in dysphagia symptoms, esophageal manometry findings, and post-procedure complications. Secondary outcomes included procedural time, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfaction. Results showed that both dilators demonstrated similar effectiveness in relieving dysphagia symptoms and improving esophageal manometry findings. However, the MVR dilator had a significantly shorter procedural time and length of hospital stay compared to BMH dilatation. No significant differences in complications or patient satisfaction were observed between the two dilators. In conclusion, both BMH and MVR dilators are effective in the treatment of achalasia, with MVR offering the advantage of shorter procedural time and hospital stay.

Ubiquitin hybrid protein gene expression during human colon cancer progression. Ubiquitin is a small protein that plays a crucial role in targeting other proteins for degradation. Dysregulation of ubiquitin-mediated processes has been implicated in the development and progression of various diseases, including cancer. In this study, we investigated the expression of ubiquitin hybrid protein gene during human colon cancer progression. Tumor samples were collected from patients at different stages of colon cancer, including primary tumors, lymph node metastases, and distant metastases. Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis was performed to measure the expression levels of ubiquitin hybrid protein gene. Our results showed a significant upregulation of ubiquitin hybrid protein gene expression in both primary tumors and metastatic lesions compared to normal colon tissue. Furthermore, the expression levels were found to increase with disease progression, with the highest levels observed in distant metastases. In conclusion, our findings suggest that ubiquitin hybrid protein gene may play a role in the progression of colon cancer and could serve as a potential biomarker for disease prognosis and targeted therapy.

Delayed subcapsular hematoma after percutaneous liver biopsy as a manifestation of warfarin toxicity.  Guidelines for the management of patients receiving chronic anticoagulation therapy who require liver biopsy are not clearly defined. Percutaneous liver biopsy is a commonly performed procedure in patients receiving chronic anticoagulation therapy. However, the management of these patients remains a challenge, as guidelines for their management are not clearly defined. This case report presents a rare manifestation of warfarin toxicity following percutaneous liver biopsy in a patient on chronic anticoagulation therapy. The patient developed a delayed subcapsular hematoma, requiring immediate intervention. The management of this complication included discontinuation of warfarin, initiation of vitamin K, and close monitoring of the patient's coagulation profile. This case highlights the need for clear guidelines on the management of patients on chronic anticoagulation therapy who require liver biopsy, in order to prevent such potentially life-threatening complications.

Is sick sinus syndrome an adenosine-mediated disease? Effects of intravenous aminophylline on sick sinus node function after pharmacologic autonomic blockade. Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) is a disorder characterized by the malfunctioning of the sinus node, resulting in abnormal heart rhythm. The etiology of SSS is not fully understood, and recent evidence suggests a potential involvement of adenosine, a purinergic signaling molecule, in its pathogenesis. This study aimed to investigate the effects of intravenous aminophylline, a non-selective adenosine receptor antagonist, on sick sinus node function after pharmacologic autonomic blockade.

Twenty patients diagnosed with SSS were enrolled in the study. Autonomic blockade was achieved by intravenous administration of atropine and propranolol. Electrophysiological studies were conducted to measure sinus node recovery time (SNRT) before and after administration of aminophylline.

Results showed a significant prolongation of SNRT after autonomic blockade, indicating impaired sinus node function. Following administration of aminophylline, there was a significant reduction in SNRT, suggesting an improvement in sick sinus node function.

These findings provide evidence for the involvement of adenosine in the pathogenesis of SSS and suggest that aminophylline may have potential therapeutic benefits in the management of this condition. Further research is warranted to fully elucidate the underlying mechanisms and to explore the clinical implications of adenosine-mediated therapy in SSS.

The use of internalised ureteric stents in renal transplant recipients. Renal transplant recipients often experience complications related to the ureter, such as strictures or leaking. Internalised ureteric stents have been used to prevent these complications and improve patient outcomes. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of internalised ureteric stents in renal transplant recipients.

Data from 100 renal transplant recipients who received internalised ureteric stents were retrospectively analyzed. The results showed that the use of internalised ureteric stents significantly reduced the incidence of ureteric complications, such as stricture or leak, compared to historical controls without stents. Furthermore, the stents were well-tolerated by the recipients with minimal adverse effects.

In conclusion, the use of internalised ureteric stents in renal transplant recipients is an effective and safe method for preventing ureteric complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize the use of internalised ureteric stents in this population.

Doppler echocardiographic evaluation of streptokinase lysis of thrombosed right-sided St.  Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. Thrombosis of prosthetic valves in patients with congenital heart defects poses a significant clinical challenge. Streptokinase has been used in the management of thrombosed St. Jude Medical valves with varying success. However, its efficacy in achieving complete lysis and the associated hemodynamic changes remain uncertain. In this study, we evaluated the Doppler echocardiographic findings before and after streptokinase lysis in patients with thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves and congenital heart defects. Our results demonstrated successful lysis in all patients, with complete resolution of thrombus on echocardiographic evaluation. Additionally, we observed significant improvement in valvular function and hemodynamics post-lysis. Our findings suggest that streptokinase lysis can be an effective therapeutic option for managing thrombosed right-sided St. Jude Medical valves in patients with congenital heart defects. Further research is warranted to determine the long-term outcomes and optimal management strategies for these patients.

Immunoprofile of mucoepidermoid carcinomas of minor salivary glands. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC) is the most common malignant neoplasm of the minor salivary glands. This study aimed to evaluate the immunoprofile of MECs to gain a better understanding of their molecular characteristics and potential therapeutic targets. Immunohistochemical staining was performed on archival tissue samples from 30 cases of MEC. The expression of various markers including cytokeratins 7 and 5/6, p63, p53, Ki-67, and CD34 was assessed. Our results showed that MECs exhibited variable staining patterns for these markers, suggesting the heterogeneity of this tumor type at the molecular level. Notably, high Ki-67 expression was associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype. These findings provide insights into the immunophenotypic characteristics of MECs and may aid in the development of targeted therapies for this malignancy. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore additional potential biomarkers.

Study of preneoplastic changes of liver cells by immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. The aim of this study was to investigate preneoplastic changes in liver cells using immunohistochemical and molecular hybridization techniques. Liver tissues from 50 patients with suspected preneoplastic lesions were analyzed. Immunohistochemical staining was performed to assess the expression levels of specific markers associated with neoplastic transformation. Additionally, molecular hybridization techniques such as fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) were used to detect specific genetic alterations. Results showed significant upregulation of markers related to cell proliferation and DNA damage in the preneoplastic lesions compared to normal liver tissue. FISH analysis revealed genetic abnormalities, including chromosomal rearrangements and gene amplifications, in a subset of the preneoplastic lesions. These findings provide insights into the early molecular changes occurring in liver cells prior to neoplastic transformation and may contribute to the development of novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for liver cancer.

Effects of tracheal irritation and hypercapnia on tracheal smooth muscle in humans. Tracheal irritation and hypercapnia have been recognized as potential factors contributing to airway hyperresponsiveness in various respiratory conditions. However, the specific effects of these stimuli on tracheal smooth muscle (TSM) in humans remain poorly understood. In this study, isolated human tracheal segments were subjected to increasing concentrations of irritant gases and elevated levels of carbon dioxide, mimicking tracheal irritation and hypercapnia, respectively. The contractile responses of TSM were measured to assess the impact of these stimuli. Results showed that tracheal irritation significantly increased TSM contractility, with a dose-dependent relationship observed. Similarly, hypercapnia induced a significant augmentation of TSM contractile responses. Furthermore, pre-treatment with specific inhibitors of bronchoconstriction pathways attenuated the enhanced contractile responses, suggesting the involvement of these signaling pathways in TSM hyperresponsiveness. These findings provide new insights into the pathophysiology of airway hyperresponsiveness and suggest potential therapeutic targets for respiratory diseases associated with tracheal irritation and hypercapnia. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore novel treatment approaches.

Orthostatic hypotension in human immunodeficiency virus infection may be the result of generalized autonomic nervous system dysfunction. Orthostatic hypotension, defined as a decrease in blood pressure upon standing, is commonly observed in individuals with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The underlying mechanisms contributing to this condition remain unclear. In this study, we investigated the possible association between orthostatic hypotension in HIV-infected individuals and autonomic nervous system dysfunction.
