Ten HIV-positive patients with orthostatic hypotension and ten HIV-positive control patients without orthostatic hypotension were included in the study. Autonomic function tests, including heart rate variability and deep breathing tests, were performed on all participants. The results revealed that HIV-infected individuals with orthostatic hypotension exhibited significantly impaired autonomic function compared to control patients without orthostatic hypotension. These findings suggest that generalized autonomic nervous system dysfunction may contribute to the development of orthostatic hypotension in HIV-infected individuals, highlighting the need for further research to better understand and manage this condition.

Overt hepatic encephalopathy precipitated by zinc deficiency. Zinc deficiency is a known cause of hepatic encephalopathy, a condition characterized by altered mental status and neuropsychiatric symptoms. This case report describes a patient who presented with overt hepatic encephalopathy that was determined to be precipitated by zinc deficiency. The patient had a history of chronic alcoholism and malnutrition, both of which are risk factors for zinc deficiency. Laboratory investigations revealed low serum zinc levels, and imaging studies showed characteristic findings of cirrhosis. The patient was treated with zinc supplementation, resulting in a significant improvement in mental status and resolution of symptoms. This case highlights the importance of considering zinc deficiency as a potential etiology in patients with hepatic encephalopathy, especially in those with risk factors such as chronic alcoholism and malnutrition. Early recognition and treatment of zinc deficiency can lead to a favorable outcome in these patients.

A randomized trial of the effect of three non-steroid anti-inflammatory agents in ameliorating cancer-induced fever.  Paraneoplastic fever is well known, and is not an uncommon problem in daily practice. Paraneoplastic fever is a common complication seen in patients with cancer, and it can significantly impact overall quality of life. The current treatment options for cancer-induced fever mainly focus on antipyretics and supportive care measures. However, there is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of non-steroid anti-inflammatory agents in ameliorating cancer-induced fever. 
To address this, a randomized trial is being conducted to investigate the effect of three different non-steroid anti-inflammatory agents in alleviating cancer-induced fever. The trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of these agents in reducing fever and improving overall symptom control in cancer patients. Preliminary data have shown promising results in terms of fever reduction after administration of these agents. The trial is ongoing, and final results are expected to provide valuable insights into the optimal management of cancer-induced fever and potential benefits of non-steroid anti-inflammatory agents in this patient population.

Idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome terminating as disseminated T-cell lymphoma. Idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) is a rare disorder characterized by persistent eosinophilia and organ involvement. We present a case of a 47-year-old male who initially presented with eosinophilia-associated symptoms, including pruritus, fatigue, weight loss, and cough. Despite conventional therapy, his condition continued to worsen, and he developed disseminated T-cell lymphoma. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of HES terminating as disseminated T-cell lymphoma. The pathogenesis of this transformation remains unknown, and further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms. Clinicians should be aware of the potential for HES to progress to lymphoma, especially in cases where conventional treatments are ineffective. Early recognition and intervention may improve outcomes in these patients.

A new method for mapping hepatic subsegment: counterstaining identification technique. Accurate identification and mapping of hepatic subsegment are crucial for surgical planning and hepatic cancer treatment. This study presents a novel method for mapping hepatic subsegments using a counterstaining identification technique. The authors utilized indocyanine green, a fluorescent dye, and combined it with a counterstain, methylene blue, to visualize hepatic subsegments. A total of 50 patients undergoing hepatectomy for hepatocellular carcinoma were included in the study. The authors successfully identified and mapped hepatic subsegments using the counterstaining technique, with a high level of accuracy and reproducibility. The results demonstrate the potential of this method as a valuable tool for hepatic subsegment mapping, which could aid surgeons in precise tumor localization and facilitate safe and effective surgical interventions for hepatic cancer.

Crohn disease in the pediatric patient: CT evaluation. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disorder that commonly affects the gastrointestinal tract in pediatric patients. This study aimed to evaluate the role of computed tomography (CT) in diagnosing and assessing the extent of Crohn's disease in this population. Retrospective analysis of CT scans from 50 pediatric patients with clinically suspected or known Crohn's disease was performed.

CT scans demonstrated characteristic findings of Crohn's disease, including bowel wall thickening, mural stratification, mural hyperenhancement, mesenteric inflammation, and complications such as strictures and fistulas. The extent of disease involvement was accurately assessed using CT, with involvement of the terminal ileum being the most common site. CT also provided valuable information regarding extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease, such as lymphadenopathy and abscess formation.

In conclusion, CT imaging plays a crucial role in the evaluation of Crohn's disease in the pediatric population, allowing for accurate diagnosis, assessment of disease activity, and detection of complications. CT should be considered as an essential imaging modality in the management of pediatric patients with Crohn's disease.

The surprising kidney-fluid mechanism for pressure control--its infinite gain! In this short paper, I have tried to explain the elation that we felt when we first realized that the kidney-fluid mechanism for controlling the arterial pressure has an infinite feedback gain property. The kidney-fluid mechanism for pressure control has long been the subject of study and fascination in the field of physiology. In this paper, we present our findings on the surprising property of this mechanism - its infinite feedback gain. Through mathematical modeling and experimental validation, we demonstrate that the kidney-fluid mechanism is able to regulate arterial pressure with remarkable precision and efficiency. This infinite gain property allows for rapid and sensitive adjustments to changes in blood volume or pressure, ensuring the maintenance of homeostasis. Our findings shed new light on the intricate mechanisms involved in blood pressure regulation and have implications for understanding and treating conditions such as hypertension.

Preoperative piroxicam for postoperative analgesia in dental surgery.  Fifty patients were allocated randomly to receive placebo or piroxicam 40 mg, 2. In a randomized controlled trial, fifty patients undergoing dental surgery were assigned to receive either placebo or preoperative piroxicam 40 mg, 2. Postoperative analgesia was assessed using a visual analogue scale (VAS) to measure pain intensity at 1, 2, 4, 6, and 24 hours after surgery. 

The results showed that patients in the piroxicam group had significantly lower VAS scores compared to those in the placebo group at all time points (p<0.05). Furthermore, the piroxicam group required fewer rescue analgesics compared to the placebo group (p<0.05). 

This study suggests that preoperative administration of piroxicam 40 mg can effectively reduce postoperative pain in dental surgery and may be considered as a viable option for improved pain management in this setting.

Lower respiratory tract infections. Lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical profile, treatment outcomes, and associated factors of LRTIs in a tertiary care hospital. A retrospective analysis of 250 patients diagnosed with LRTIs was conducted over a one-year period. The majority of patients presented with cough, fever, and respiratory distress. Radiological investigations revealed consolidations and infiltrates in the lungs. Empiric antibiotic therapy was initiated based on guidelines, and a favorable response was observed in 80% of cases. However, 20% of patients required escalation of therapy due to worsening clinical condition or confirmed bacterial etiology. Advanced age, comorbidities, and delayed initiation of treatment were associated with poor outcomes. This study emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate management strategies for LRTIs to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Experimental retinal branch vein occlusion in miniature pigs induces local tissue hypoxia and vasoproliferative microangiopathy. Retinal branch vein occlusion (BRVO) is a common cause of vision loss, and its pathophysiology remains poorly understood. This study aimed to develop a miniature pig model of BRVO to investigate the mechanisms underlying retinal hypoxia and vasoproliferative microangiopathy. BRVO was induced in the eyes of eight miniature pigs using laser photocoagulation. The occluded veins exhibited persistent venous dilatation and tortuosity, leading to increased intraocular pressure and subsequent retinal hypoxia. Histological analysis revealed the presence of neovascularization, both within and beyond the occluded vein. Immunohistochemistry demonstrated increased expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and its receptors, suggesting a key role in the development of vasoproliferative microangiopathy. This novel miniature pig model of BRVO provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of retinal hypoxia and neovascularization, and may facilitate the development of new treatment strategies for BRVO-related vision loss.

A seromuscular stripping method to create a nipple valve without metal stapling for continent urinary reservoir. Creating a nipple valve without the use of metal stapling in continent urinary reservoir surgery is described. A new technique using a seromuscular stripping method is presented as an alternative to the traditional metal stapling method for creating a functional nipple valve. The procedure was performed on 15 patients, all of whom had undergone a continent urinary diversion for various indications. The seromuscular stripping technique involved carefully stripping the seromuscular layer of the bowel segment to create a ridge, which was then sutured to form the nipple valve. Post-operative outcomes were evaluated, including continence rates and complications. The results showed that the seromuscular stripping method successfully created a functional nipple valve in all patients, with a continence rate of 93% at one year post-operatively. Complications were minimal, with only one patient experiencing valve stenosis requiring revision. This technique provides a safe and effective alternative to metal stapling for creating a continent urinary reservoir nipple valve.

Standards for evaluating results of interventional therapy for peripheral vascular disease. Evaluation of interventional therapy for peripheral vascular disease (PVD) requires standardized criteria for accurate assessment. This study aimed to establish such standards by examining key outcome measures and their significance. A total of 200 patients with PVD who underwent interventional therapy were included. Angiographic analysis revealed improvement in vessel patency in 150 patients (75%), while the remaining 50 (25%) showed no improvement. Functional outcomes were assessed by measuring ankle-brachial index (ABI) and peak systolic velocity (PSV). In the improved group, ABI increased by a mean of 0.9 and PSV increased by 50 cm/s, while in the non-improved group, ABI increased by 0.3 and PSV increased by 10 cm/s. The improved group also exhibited a significant reduction in symptoms and improved quality of life compared to the non-improved group. A composite score incorporating angiographic, ABI, and PSV findings differentiated between successful and unsuccessful interventions. These standardized criteria provide a valuable framework for evaluating the efficacy of interventional therapy in PVD, aiding in treatment decisions and improving patient outcomes.

Hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists. H2-receptor antagonists are commonly used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcers by reducing gastric acid secretion. However, recent studies have suggested that these medications may have additional effects on the cardiovascular system. This study aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects of H2-receptor antagonists in healthy individuals. Twenty volunteers were administered either a single dose of an H2-receptor antagonist or a placebo, and their cardiovascular parameters were monitored. Results showed that H2-receptor antagonists significantly reduced heart rate and systemic vascular resistance compared to placebo. These findings suggest that H2-receptor antagonists may have a direct impact on cardiovascular function, potentially influencing blood pressure regulation and cardiovascular outcomes. Further research is required to fully understand the implications of these hemodynamic effects.

Acute water intoxication as a complication of urine drug testing in the workplace Urine drug testing is now mandatory in many industries. Acute water intoxication is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of urine drug testing in the workplace. We present here three cases of acute water intoxication that occurred as a result of excessive fluid consumption during the preparation for urine drug testing. All three patients experienced severe hyponatremia, with serum sodium levels ranging from 115 to 125 mmol/L. Clinical manifestations included nausea, vomiting, headache, confusion, and seizures. Prompt recognition and treatment with fluid restriction and hypertonic saline were essential in reversing the hyponatremia and preventing further neurological complications. Employers and healthcare providers should be aware of the potential risks associated with excessive fluid consumption during urine drug testing and take appropriate measures to prevent acute water intoxication.

Assessing the severity of dementia.  Patient and caregiver. The severity of dementia can have significant implications for patient care and management. This study aimed to assess the agreement between patient self-report and caregiver report in determining the severity of dementia. A total of 100 patient-caregiver dyads were recruited from a memory clinic. Patients were diagnosed with different stages of dementia based on standardized cognitive tests, while caregivers completed validated questionnaires assessing the severity of patient symptoms and functional impairment. The results showed a moderate level of agreement between patient and caregiver ratings of dementia severity (κ = 0.52, p < 0.001). However, when examining specific domains such as memory, language, and executive function, the agreement was notably lower. Caregivers tended to rate symptoms as more severe than patients themselves, particularly in the early stages of dementia. These findings indicate the importance of considering both patient and caregiver perspectives when assessing dementia severity and highlight the potential for discrepancies between self-report and caregiver report. Further research is needed to explore the factors influencing these discrepancies and their implications for patient management.

Evaluation of the fine needle aspiration biopsy in the preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules. Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) is widely used in the evaluation of thyroid nodules. However, its reliability in preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules remains uncertain. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of FNAB in identifying malignant thyroid nodules and determine its role in preoperative decision-making.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients with cold thyroid nodules who underwent FNAB and subsequent surgical resection. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), and diagnostic accuracy of FNAB were calculated. Additionally, the impact of FNAB results on surgical decision-making and patient outcomes was assessed.

Among the included patients, FNAB demonstrated a sensitivity of 78%, specificity of 92%, PPV of 83%, NPV of 90%, and diagnostic accuracy of 88% in identifying malignant thyroid nodules. The FNAB results influenced the surgical decision-making process in 65% of cases, with 90% concordance between FNAB results and final histopathology.

In conclusion, FNAB is a valuable tool in the preoperative selection of cold thyroid nodules, providing high diagnostic accuracy and influencing surgical decision-making. Further studies are warranted to assess its impact on long-term patient outcomes.

Suppressive effects of visceral tumor on the generation of antitumor T cells for adoptive immunotherapy. The immune system plays a critical role in the recognition and elimination of tumor cells. However, tumors have evolved various mechanisms to evade immune surveillance, including the induction of immunosuppressive effects. In this study, we investigated the impact of visceral tumors on the generation of antitumor T cells for adoptive immunotherapy. We utilized a murine model of visceral tumor growth and found that the presence of such tumors suppressed the generation of tumor-specific T cells in the spleen and lymph nodes. Furthermore, we observed a significant decrease in the production of interferon-gamma, a key cytokine involved in antitumor immune responses, by T cells isolated from tumor-bearing mice. We also demonstrated that the suppressive effects of the tumor were mediated, at least in part, by the upregulation of inhibitory molecules on antigen-presenting cells. These findings highlight the need to consider the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment when designing strategies for adoptive immunotherapy in cancer patients.

Regional differences in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells. Understanding the intranodal distribution of tumor cells within regional lymph nodes is crucial for predicting the spread and progression of cancer. This study aimed to investigate the regional differences in intranodal distribution of tumor cells in lymph node metastases. Lymph nodes from 50 patients diagnosed with various types of cancer were analyzed using immunohistochemistry and digital imaging. The distribution of tumor cells within the lymph nodes was quantitatively measured and compared between different regions. Significant differences in tumor cell distribution were observed, with a higher concentration of tumor cells in the central regions of the lymph nodes compared to the peripheral regions. These regional differences were consistent across different types of cancer and correlated with the size and type of lymph node metastasis. Furthermore, the intranodal distribution of tumor cells was associated with the presence of lymphatic vessel invasion and nodal extracapsular extension. These findings highlight the importance of considering regional differences in intranodal tumor cell distribution for accurate staging and prognosis in cancer patients.

Thyroidectomy under local anesthesia. Thyroidectomy is a common surgical procedure typically performed under general anesthesia. However, some patients may not be suitable candidates for general anesthesia due to medical reasons or personal preference. This case report presents a 45-year-old female patient who underwent a total thyroidectomy under local anesthesia. The patient had a history of significant comorbidities, including severe obstructive sleep apnea and congestive heart failure. The surgery was performed successfully using a combination of local infiltration anesthesia and conscious sedation. The patient remained comfortable throughout the procedure, with minimal pain and no complications. This case highlights the feasibility and safety of performing thyroidectomies under local anesthesia in carefully selected patients, particularly those who may have higher surgical risks associated with general anesthesia. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the efficacy and long-term outcomes of this approach.

Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis for treatment of twin-twin transfusion syndrome.  Acute severe twin-twin transfusion syndrome occurs in about 1% of monochorionic twin gestations. Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis has been proposed as a potential treatment for acute severe twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) in monochorionic twin gestations. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this intervention. A retrospective analysis was performed on 50 cases of acute severe TTTS that underwent aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis. The procedure involved serial amniocentesis to drain excess amniotic fluid from the recipient twin's sac. Outcomes including perinatal survival, neurodevelopmental outcomes, and complications were assessed. The overall perinatal survival rate was 78%, with 16% of cases resulting in the survival of both twins. Neurodevelopmental outcomes were favorable in the surviving infants. Complications such as membranous decompression syndrome and preterm delivery were observed, but overall, the procedure was deemed safe. Aggressive therapeutic amniocentesis appears to be a viable option for the treatment of acute severe TTTS, providing improved perinatal survival rates and favorable neurodevelopmental outcomes, albeit with associated risks and complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these findings.

Dissection of the cardinal ligament in radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer with emphasis on the lateral ligament. Radical hysterectomy is a standard surgical treatment for cervical cancer. However, there is still debate regarding the optimal dissection technique, particularly with respect to the cardinal ligament and lateral ligament. This study aims to investigate the dissection of the cardinal ligament, with a specific focus on the lateral ligament.

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 200 patients who underwent radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer. The dissection of the cardinal ligament was described in detail, and the presence of lateral ligament involvement was assessed. The outcomes of interest included intraoperative complications, lymph node metastasis, and disease-free survival.

The results showed that the majority of patients (80%) had lateral ligament involvement, which was associated with a higher risk of lymph node metastasis (p < 0.001). However, there was no significant difference in intraoperative complications between patients with or without lateral ligament involvement. Moreover, disease-free survival was not significantly affected by lateral ligament involvement (p = 0.345).

In conclusion, the dissection of the cardinal ligament in radical hysterectomy for cervical cancer should include adequate attention to the lateral ligament. Although lateral ligament involvement is common, it does not appear to have a significant impact on disease-free survival. Further studies are warranted to confirm these findings and optimize the dissection technique.

Hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin in patients on dialysis.  Eighteen patients on chronic hemodialysis with renal anemia were treated with recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO). The hemodynamic effects of partial correction of chronic anemia by recombinant human erythropoietin (r-HuEPO) were evaluated in 18 patients on chronic hemodialysis. The patients were treated with r-HuEPO to achieve a target hemoglobin level of 11-12 g/dL. Hemodynamic parameters, including systolic and diastolic blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, and cardiac output, were measured at baseline and after 12 weeks of r-HuEPO therapy. The results showed a significant increase in hemoglobin levels from 8.5 g/dL at baseline to 11.9 g/dL after treatment. There was also a significant decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, and an increase in cardiac output. These findings suggest that partial correction of chronic anemia with r-HuEPO in patients on dialysis has favorable hemodynamic effects, potentially improving cardiovascular outcomes in this population.

Peritoneal closure or non-closure at cesarean.  The value of peritoneal closure at the time of cesarean birth was evaluated prospectively. The study aimed to determine the impact of peritoneal closure on postoperative outcomes in cesarean births. A total of 200 consecutive patients undergoing cesarean section were included in the study and allocated into two groups: peritoneal closure (n=100) and non-closure (n=100). The primary outcome measures were the incidence of postoperative complications, such as wound infection, wound dehiscence, and intra-abdominal collection. The secondary outcome measures included the length of hospital stay and the need for postoperative interventions. The results showed no significant difference in the incidence of postoperative complications between the two groups (p>0.05). Additionally, there was no difference in the length of hospital stay or the need for postoperative interventions. Therefore, the study suggests that peritoneal closure may not provide additional benefits in cesarean births.

Use of a central 10 degrees field and size V stimulus to evaluate and monitor small central islands of vision in end stage glaucoma. End stage glaucoma often leads to the development of small central islands of vision, which can greatly impact the visual function and quality of life of affected individuals. In this study, we investigated the use of a central 10 degrees field and size V stimulus to assess and monitor these small central islands of vision in patients with end stage glaucoma. A total of 40 patients with end stage glaucoma were included in the study. Visual field testing using the central 10 degrees field and size V stimulus demonstrated improved detection of small central islands of vision compared to standard visual field testing methods. Furthermore, longitudinal monitoring using this technique revealed stability or progression of the small central islands of vision over time. Our findings suggest that the use of a central 10 degrees field and size V stimulus can be a valuable tool for evaluating and monitoring visual function in patients with end stage glaucoma.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. Myotonic heart disease is a rare condition characterized by prolonged contraction of the cardiac muscle. It often presents with symptoms such as palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath. This study aimed to provide a clinical follow-up of patients with myotonic heart disease to evaluate their long-term outcomes. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, and their medical records were reviewed. The average follow-up period was 5 years. The results showed that patients with myotonic heart disease had a high risk of developing arrhythmias, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. Regular monitoring and appropriate management strategies are crucial in the management of myotonic heart disease to improve overall patient outcomes.

Synergism of herpes simplex virus and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines in cell transformation. The synergistic effects of herpes simplex virus (HSV) and tobacco-specific N'-nitrosamines (TSNAs) on cell transformation were investigated in this study. Human fibroblast cells were infected with HSV and exposed to various concentrations of TSNAs. Cell transformation was assessed using colony formation assays and measurement of cell proliferation rates. It was observed that the combination of HSV infection and TSNAs exposure significantly increased cell transformation compared to HSV infection or TSNAs exposure alone. Furthermore, the synergistic effects were dose-dependent, with higher concentrations of TSNAs leading to greater cell transformation. These findings suggest that there is a synergism between HSV and TSNAs in promoting cell transformation, potentially increasing the risk of developing tobacco-related cancers in individuals infected with HSV. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop preventive strategies.

Home blood pressure readings in borderline hypertensive patients. Home blood pressure (BP) monitoring has gained popularity as a reliable method for assessing BP control in hypertensive patients. However, its utility in borderline hypertensive patients remains uncertain. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and accuracy of home BP monitoring in this population. A total of 100 borderline hypertensive patients were enrolled and instructed on the proper use of a home BP monitoring device. They were advised to measure their BP at both morning and evening for one week. The results were compared to simultaneous clinic BP measurements. The mean age of the participants was 45 years, with 52% being female. The mean clinic BP was 135/85 mmHg, while the mean home BP was 128/82 mmHg. There was a strong correlation between clinic and home BP measurements (r=0.82, p<0.001). The overall agreement between the two methods was good, with a mean difference of 7/3 mmHg. In conclusion, home BP monitoring is feasible and accurate in borderline hypertensive patients, providing a valuable tool for assessing BP control outside of the clinic setting.

Elevated serum bromide concentrations following repeated halothane anaesthesia in a child.  A 20-month-old child received 25 brief halothane general anaesthetics over a five-week period to allow cranial irradiation treatments for a posterior fossa ependymoma. Following each anaesthetic, the child developed marked respiratory depression, which was reversed with naloxone.  Despite adequate hydration and normal renal function, the child developed symptoms consistent with bromide intoxication, including excessive salivation, facial erythema, and lethargy.  Serum bromide concentrations measured after 25 anaesthetics were elevated to a mean of 9.8 mg/dL.  This concentration is more than 20 times the normal therapeutic range and similar to concentrations reported to produce symptoms of intoxication in literature.  This case emphasizes the importance of considering halothane as a source of bromide ions and highlights the potential for elevated serum bromide concentrations following repeated halothane anaesthesia.  Medical professionals should be aware of potential complications associated with repeated exposure to halothane and consider alternative anaesthetic agents when feasible.

Regional differences in the intranodal distribution of tumor cells. The intranodal distribution of tumor cells in regional lymph nodes has been studied in 50 patients with metastatic melanoma. The distribution patterns were evaluated using immunohistochemistry to identify tumor cells within the lymph nodes. Regional differences were observed in the distribution of tumor cells within the lymph nodes, with some nodes showing a higher concentration of tumor cells in the cortex, while others had a higher concentration in the medulla. Furthermore, nodal areas near the primary tumor site exhibited a higher number of tumor cells compared to remote nodal areas. These findings suggest that the intranodal distribution of tumor cells is not uniform and may be influenced by regional factors such as lymphatic drainage patterns and proximity to the primary tumor site. Understanding these regional differences may have implications for the evaluation of lymph node involvement and the design of targeted therapies for metastatic melanoma. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms driving these regional differences in tumor cell distribution within lymph nodes.

A protocol for the investigation of pregnancy loss. Pregnancy loss is a devastating event that affects many women and their partners. Understanding the underlying causes of pregnancy loss is important for appropriate management and future prevention. This abstract aims to outline a comprehensive protocol for the investigation of pregnancy loss. The protocol includes a thorough medical history, physical examination, and laboratory investigations to identify potential etiological factors such as chromosomal abnormalities, maternal infectious diseases, immune factors, hormonal imbalances, and anatomical abnormalities. Genetic counseling and testing, including karyotyping and microarray analysis, are recommended to detect chromosomal abnormalities in both parents. Screening for maternal infections, including rubella, syphilis, and toxoplasmosis, is essential. Assessment of hormonal levels, such as progesterone and thyroid hormones, can be informative. Additionally, anatomic evaluation using ultrasound and hysterosalpingography can identify structural abnormalities of the uterus and fallopian tubes. Overall, a systematic approach to the investigation of pregnancy loss is crucial in order to provide appropriate counseling, management, and subsequent prevention strategies.

Premature alveolar bone loss in Erdheim-Chester disease.  Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare histiocytosis also known as lipoid granulomatosis. Erdheim-Chester disease (ECD) is a rare non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis characterized by lipid-laden histiocytes infiltrating multiple organs. This report describes a case of ECD presenting with premature alveolar bone loss, a manifestation not previously reported in the literature. A 48-year-old male presented with jaw pain and loosening teeth. Cone-beam computed tomography revealed severe alveolar bone loss and tooth mobility. Histopathological examination of a bone biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of ECD, showing infiltrating foamy histiocytes. The patient was treated with a combination of interferon-alpha and prednisone, resulting in stabilization of the disease and improvement of bone density. This case highlights a rare manifestation of ECD and emphasizes the importance of considering ECD in the differential diagnosis of premature alveolar bone loss.

A recurrent pelvic desmoid tumor successfully treated with tamoxifen. Desmoid tumor is a rare fibroblastic neoplasm that typically arises in the musculoaponeurotic structures in the abdomen and pelvis. We report a case of a recurrent pelvic desmoid tumor in a 35-year-old female that was successfully treated with tamoxifen. The patient presented with pelvic pain and a progressively enlarging mass, which was confirmed to be a desmoid tumor on pathological examination. After surgical resection, the tumor recurred, and given the lack of effective treatment options, tamoxifen was initiated. Over the course of 12 months, the tumor showed significant regression without any adverse effects. This case highlights the potential utility of tamoxifen as a non-surgical treatment option for recurrent desmoid tumors, particularly in cases where resection is not feasible or has failed.

Push-enteroscopy for diagnosis of patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. Gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin presents a diagnostic challenge for clinicians. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic yield and safety of push-enteroscopy in patients with gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent push-enteroscopy for gastrointestinal bleeding between January 2015 and December 2019. The medical records of 135 patients were reviewed, and data on patient characteristics, procedure details, and outcomes were collected. The diagnostic yield of push-enteroscopy was assessed based on the identification of a bleeding source. Safety was evaluated by recording any procedure-related complications. The overall diagnostic yield of push-enteroscopy was 53.3%, with the most common bleeding sources being angioectasias and ulcers. Procedure-related complications were reported in 7.4% of patients, with the majority being minor and self-limited. Push-enteroscopy is a safe and effective tool for diagnosing gastrointestinal bleeding of obscure origin. Its high diagnostic yield suggests that it should be considered early in the diagnostic workup of these patients to guide further management and achieve favorable outcomes.

Possible role of leukotrienes in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori.  This study was done to evaluate the role of leukotrienes (LTs) in gastritis associated with Campylobacter pylori. The aim of this study was to investigate the involvement of leukotrienes (LTs) in Campylobacter pylori-associated gastritis. Gastric biopsy specimens were obtained from patients diagnosed with C. pylori infection and examined for LT levels using immunohistochemistry and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The results revealed a significant increase in LT expression in the gastric mucosa of patients with C. pylori-associated gastritis compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, there was a positive correlation between LT levels and the severity of gastritis. These findings suggest a potential role for LTs in the pathogenesis of gastritis associated with C. pylori infection, providing insights for future therapeutic interventions.

Cochlear implant flap complications. Cochlear implantation has become a standard treatment for severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. However, complications related to the surgical procedure can occur, including flap complications. This retrospective study aimed to analyze the incidence, management, and outcomes of cochlear implant flap complications in a cohort of patients. A total of 58 patients with flap complications were identified, with an incidence rate of 4.6%. The most common complication was flap necrosis (34.5%), followed by infection (31.0%) and dehiscence (24.1%). Surgical revision was necessary in 75.9% of cases, and flap revision was the most common procedure. Overall, flap complications were associated with prolonged hospital stays and higher rates of reimplantation. The study highlights the importance of careful flap management and close follow-up to minimize flap complications and optimize outcomes for cochlear implant recipients.

Indications for use of ketoconazole in management of metastatic prostate cancer. Metastatic prostate cancer (MPC) remains a major challenge in clinical oncology due to its high mortality rate and limited treatment options. Ketoconazole, an antifungal agent, has shown promise in the management of MPC. Its action as an inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes leads to a reduction in circulating androgens, which are known to promote the progression of prostate cancer. In addition, ketoconazole has been found to inhibit adrenal androgen synthesis and may further suppress androgen production in MPC patients. Clinical trials have demonstrated that ketoconazole, either as monotherapy or in combination with other agents, can lead to a significant reduction in prostate-specific antigen levels and tumor burden. Adverse effects such as liver toxicity and drug interactions should be carefully monitored. With further investigation, ketoconazole may prove to be a valuable therapeutic option in the management of MPC.

Middle cerebral artery strokes causing homonymous hemianopia: positron emission tomography. Homonymous hemianopia is a common clinical manifestation of middle cerebral artery (MCA) strokes. However, the underlying pathophysiological mechanism and cerebral blood flow alterations in these patients remain poorly understood. In this study, we utilized positron emission tomography (PET) to investigate the cerebral glucose metabolism and blood flow changes in patients with MCA stroke-induced homonymous hemianopia. Our results demonstrated significant reductions in glucose metabolism and blood flow in the affected hemisphere, predominantly involving the occipital and parietal lobes. Furthermore, we observed a positive correlation between the severity of hemianopia and the degree of hypoperfusion. These findings provide valuable insights into the pathophysiology of homonymous hemianopia following MCA strokes and highlight the potential of PET imaging in assessing cerebral blood flow alterations in stroke patients.

Tuberculous psoas muscle abscess following chemoprophylaxis with isoniazid in a patient with human immunodeficiency virus infection. Tuberculous psoas muscle abscess is a rare but serious complication of chemoprophylaxis with isoniazid in patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. We report a case of a 35-year-old HIV-infected male who developed a psoas muscle abscess following isoniazid prophylaxis for latent tuberculosis infection. The patient presented with fever, right hip pain, and limitation of movement. Imaging studies revealed a large psoas abscess, which was confirmed by microbiological culture showing Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The abscess was drained surgically, and the patient was started on anti-tuberculosis treatment. This case highlights the importance of considering tuberculous psoas abscess as a potential complication in HIV-infected patients receiving isoniazid prophylaxis. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent further complications and improve patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to explore the risk factors and optimal management strategies for this rare complication.

Aggravation of human and experimental myasthenia gravis by contrast media. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. Contrast media (CM) is commonly used in various medical procedures, but its potential to aggravate MG symptoms has been reported. We present a case of a 57-year-old woman with known MG who developed worsened weakness and respiratory distress following a computed tomography scan with intravenous contrast. This case highlights the importance of caution in administering CM to patients with MG and the need for close monitoring of respiratory function. Physicians should be aware of this potential complication and consider alternative imaging options in patients with known MG to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

Prospective randomized comparison of intravesical with percutaneous bacillus Calmette-Guerin versus intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin in superficial bladder cancer. Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) immunotherapy has proven effective in treating superficial bladder cancer, however, the optimal delivery method is still debated. This prospective, randomized study compared the efficacy and safety of intravesical BCG with percutaneous BCG administration in patients with superficial bladder cancer. A total of 120 patients were divided into two groups: one receiving intravesical BCG and the other percutaneous BCG. The primary outcome measured was disease recurrence, while secondary outcomes included adverse events and quality of life. After a follow-up period of 24 months, the recurrence rate in the intravesical BCG group was significantly lower compared to the percutaneous BCG group (p<0.05). Adverse events were comparable between the two groups, with no significant differences in quality of life. These findings suggest that intravesical BCG is the superior method for delivering BCG immunotherapy in the management of superficial bladder cancer. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results.

Vasal injuries during childhood and their effect on subsequent fertility. III.  Association between childhood vasal injuries and subsequent fertility in adult males.  Retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of adult males who had experienced vasal injuries during childhood, compared to a control group with no history of vasal injuries.  Fertility outcomes, including semen analysis and successful pregnancy rates, were evaluated.  Results showed a significant decrease in sperm count, motility, and morphology in the vasal injury group compared to controls. Additionally, the vasal injury group had a lower rate of successful pregnancies. These findings suggest that childhood vasal injuries can have a lasting impact on male fertility in adulthood. Possible mechanisms of this association include disruption of the vas deferens structure and impaired sperm transport. Further research is warranted to explore potential interventions to mitigate the effects of childhood vasal injuries on future fertility.

Autosomal dominant neovascular inflammatory vitreoretinopathy. Autosomal dominant neovascular inflammatory vitreoretinopathy (ADNIV) is a rare inherited eye disorder characterized by retinal inflammation, neovascularization, and vitreous opacities. The condition typically presents in childhood or early adulthood and can lead to severe vision loss if left untreated. The exact mechanism behind ADNIV remains unknown, but mutations in the membrane frizzled-related protein (MFRP) gene have been identified as the causative genetic defect in most cases. MFRP is thought to play a role in retinal development and maintenance of the blood-retinal barrier. Clinical manifestations of ADNIV include floaters, blurred vision, and progressive visual impairment. Treatment options are limited, with anti-inflammatory drugs and laser photocoagulation being the mainstay of management. Genetic counseling is crucial for affected individuals and their families due to the autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of ADNIV. Further research is needed to elucidate the pathogenesis of this condition and develop targeted therapies to improve outcomes for affected individuals.

Pharmacokinetics of tiaprofenic acid after oral administration in fasting patients during and between migraine attacks.  This study examined the pharmacokinetics of 300 mg of tiaprofenic acid, a NSAID belonging to the 2-arylpropionic class, as a single oral dose, in 10 migraine patients during and out of migraine attacks.  Plasma concentration of tiaprofenic acid was determined by HPLC analysis. During a migraine attack, the absorption of tiaprofenic acid was slower compared to the absorption during the interictal period. The peak plasma concentration (Cmax) was significantly lower during a migraine attack compared to the interictal period (p<0.05). The time to reach Cmax (Tmax) was longer during a migraine attack compared to the interictal period (p<0.05). The area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) was significantly smaller during a migraine attack compared to the interictal period (p<0.05), indicating reduced systemic exposure. These findings suggest that the pharmacokinetics of tiaprofenic acid are influenced by the presence of a migraine attack, potentially impacting its clinical efficacy and dosage regimen in migraine patients. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications.

Progressive coma after the transsphenoidal decompression of a pituitary adenoma with marked suprasellar extension: report of two cases. We present two cases of progressive coma following transsphenoidal decompression of pituitary adenomas with marked suprasellar extension. In both cases, the preoperative magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated large pituitary adenomas extending into the suprasellar region. Transsphenoidal surgery was performed successfully, but both patients developed neurological deterioration in the postoperative period. Repeat magnetic resonance imaging revealed massive suprasellar hematoma compressing the brainstem. Emergent surgical evacuation of the hematoma was performed, resulting in clinical improvement in both cases. The pathophysiology of progressive coma following transsphenoidal surgery for pituitary adenomas is unclear, but it may be related to hemorrhage into the suprasellar region. These cases highlight the importance of close postoperative monitoring and prompt recognition and treatment of complications in patients undergoing transsphenoidal decompression of pituitary adenomas with suprasellar extension.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. Rectal carcinoid tumors are rare neuroendocrine neoplasms with varying clinical behaviors. In order to better understand the genetic makeup of these tumors, DNA ploidy pattern analysis was performed on 20 cases of rectal carcinoid tumors. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that 14 cases (70%) exhibited DNA aneuploidy, while 6 cases (30%) showed diploid DNA content. Interestingly, the aneuploid tumors displayed a higher histological grade and larger tumor size compared to the diploid tumors. Additionally, patients with aneuploid tumors tended to have a poorer prognosis, with a higher likelihood of lymph node involvement and distant metastasis. These findings suggest that DNA ploidy pattern analysis may serve as a useful prognostic marker for rectal carcinoid tumors, providing valuable insight into their clinical behavior and potential for aggressive disease progression. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms driving DNA aneuploidy in rectal carcinoid tumors.

The prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the Peoples Republic of China.  Meta-analysis on data from 16 (two volunteer and 14 endoscopic) studies ahs been performed to investigate the prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection in the stomachs of individuals within the Peoples Republic of China.  In this survey covering 2216 cases (89 volunteers and 2127 endoscopy patients), the incidence of H. pylori infection was found to be high, with an overall prevalence of 63%. The analysis revealed significant regional variation, with the highest prevalence observed in the Northern region (74%) and the lowest in the Southern region (54%). Age was also found to be a significant factor, with older individuals demonstrating a higher prevalence of infection. These findings indicate a substantial burden of H. pylori infection in the Chinese population and emphasize the need for targeted prevention and treatment strategies to reduce the associated morbidity and mortality.

Drop attacks with Meniere's syndrome. Drop attacks are a debilitating and frightening symptom experienced by some patients with Meniere's syndrome. These attacks, characterized by sudden falls without loss of consciousness, pose a significant risk to the affected individuals. The etiology and pathophysiology of drop attacks in Meniere's syndrome remain unclear, making accurate diagnosis and effective treatment challenging. Through a retrospective analysis of clinical data and symptom presentation, we aimed to elucidate the characteristics and potential triggers of drop attacks in patients with Meniere's syndrome. Our findings revealed that drop attacks predominantly occurred during episodes of vertigo and were associated with severe disequilibrium and hearing loss. While drop attacks were not significantly correlated with specific triggers, they were more frequently reported in patients with longer disease duration and higher frequency of vertigo attacks. These results highlight the complex nature of drop attacks in Meniere's syndrome and emphasize the need for further research to improve diagnostic strategies and develop targeted interventions.

Fetal imaging in the skeletal dysplasias. Skeletal dysplasias are a heterogeneous group of genetic disorders that affect the growth and development of the skeletal system in fetuses. Fetal imaging plays a crucial role in the prenatal diagnosis and management of these conditions. This study aimed to evaluate the utility of various imaging modalities, including ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and three-dimensional (3D) imaging, in the detection and characterization of skeletal dysplasias in the prenatal period. A comprehensive review of the literature was conducted, and several case studies were included to illustrate the imaging findings of different types of skeletal dysplasias. The results demonstrated that fetal imaging, particularly MRI and 3D imaging, can provide valuable information regarding the precise diagnosis, prognosis, and management options for skeletal dysplasias. Further research is needed to optimize the imaging protocols and enhance the accuracy and reproducibility of fetal skeletal dysplasia diagnosis.

Code 9: a systematic approach for responding to medical emergencies occurring in and around a hospital. Code 9 is a structured system designed to effectively respond to medical emergencies that occur within and around a hospital. This study aims to evaluate the implementation and outcomes of Code 9 in a large urban hospital setting. A retrospective analysis of Code 9 activations over a one-year period was conducted, reviewing medical records, incident reports, and staff interviews. Results showed that Code 9 was successfully activated 87% of the time, with an average response time of 3 minutes and 42 seconds. The most common reasons for activation included cardiac arrest, respiratory distress, and trauma. The majority of Code 9 activations occurred in patient care areas, and the most frequently reported outcomes were successful resuscitation and transfer to a higher level of care. This study highlights the importance and effectiveness of Code 9 in improving patient outcomes during medical emergencies.

Dexamethasone increases plasma levels of albendazole. Albendazole is a widely used anthelmintic drug that exhibits poor systemic bioavailability. In order to enhance its plasma levels, the co-administration of dexamethasone has been suggested due to its potential to influence drug metabolism and transport mechanisms. This study aimed to investigate the effect of dexamethasone on the plasma levels of albendazole in rats. Twelve male Sprague-Dawley rats were divided into two groups, with one group receiving dexamethasone and the other serving as a control. After administration of albendazole, plasma samples were collected at different time points. The results showed that the plasma levels of albendazole were significantly higher in the dexamethasone-treated group compared to the control group. These findings suggest that dexamethasone can enhance the systemic exposure of albendazole, potentially improving its efficacy in the treatment of parasitic infections. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and evaluate the clinical implications of this drug combination.

Clinical review 16: Parathyroid hormone-related proteins: coming of age in the 1990s. The discovery of parathyroid hormone-related proteins (PTHrPs) has greatly advanced our understanding of their role in various physiological processes. This review examines the emerging knowledge regarding the functions and regulation of PTHrPs, with a particular focus on their involvement in the pathogenesis of diseases such as cancer, osteoporosis, and hypercalcemia. PTHrPs have been found to play a crucial role in bone development, calcium homeostasis, and cell proliferation. Additionally, recent studies have demonstrated their involvement in angiogenesis and immune modulation. The therapeutic potential of targeting PTHrPs is also discussed, highlighting the development of PTHrP antagonists as potential treatments for cancer and other diseases. Overall, PTHrPs have emerged as important mediators in various physiological and pathological processes, and further research is needed to fully unravel their complex functions and therapeutic potential.

Acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis associated with interleukin-2 and lymphokine-activated killer cell therapy.  A case of unusual cholecystitis that developed on completion of interleukin-2 and lymphokine-activated killer cell therapy is described. We present a case of an unusual cholecystitis, known as acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis, which occurred following administration of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and lymphokine-activated killer (LAK) cell therapy. A 58-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma received IL-2 and LAK cell therapy as part of his treatment. After completion of the therapy, the patient developed severe abdominal pain and laboratory findings consistent with cholecystitis. Imaging studies revealed gallbladder wall thickening without gallstones. A cholecystectomy was performed, and histopathological examination showed marked lymphoeosinophilic infiltration of the gallbladder wall, consistent with acalculus lymphoeosinophilic cholecystitis. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of this specific type of cholecystitis associated with IL-2 and LAK cell therapy. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential risk factors for developing this condition.

Mutagen sensitivity in patients with head and neck cancers: a biologic marker for risk of multiple primary malignancies.  Eighty-four patients with head and neck cancers were evaluated for in vitro sensitivity to mutagens and then followed longitudinally for development of multiple primary malignancies. Mutagen sensitivity (MS) is a potential biological marker for the risk of developing multiple primary malignancies (MPM) in patients with head and neck cancers. In this study, a total of 84 patients with head and neck cancers were assessed for in vitro sensitivity to mutagens and subsequently monitored for the occurrence of MPM over a longitudinal follow-up. The results demonstrated a significant correlation between elevated MS and the subsequent development of MPM. Patients with higher MS levels had a greater likelihood of developing additional primary malignancies compared to those with lower MS levels. These findings suggest that MS may serve as a useful predictive tool for identifying patients at a higher risk of MPM and may contribute to improved management strategies in this population. Further research is warranted to validate these results and explore the underlying mechanisms of mutagen sensitivity in the context of multiple primary malignancies.

Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction during long-term hemodialysis. Pseudotumor of the craniocervical junction is a rare complication that can occur during long-term hemodialysis, affecting the quality of life and neurological status of patients. This study aimed to investigate the incidence and characteristics of pseudotumor in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis. A total of 25 patients with pseudotumor were identified and compared with 50 controls. The mean duration of hemodialysis was significantly longer in the pseudotumor group. Patients with pseudotumor presented with symptoms such as headache, neck pain, and neurological deficits. Radiographic evaluation revealed an enlargement of the craniocervical junction with significant crowding and compression of surrounding structures. Surgical intervention was required in 60% of patients to relieve symptoms and reduce the risk of neurological deterioration. Our findings suggest that clinicians should be aware of the potential for pseudotumor development in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis and consider appropriate interventions to improve patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for this condition.

Edwards' syndrome after the replacement of cryopreserved-thawed embryos. Edwards' syndrome, also known as trisomy 18, is a chromosomal disorder characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18. It is associated with multiple structural abnormalities and severe intellectual disability. In this case report, we present a rare occurrence of Edwards' syndrome in a pregnancy following the replacement of cryopreserved-thawed embryos during in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment. The patient had a history of recurrent miscarriages and opted for IVF treatment. The embryos were cryopreserved at the blastocyst stage and later thawed for transfer. Unfortunately, prenatal genetic testing confirmed trisomy 18 in the fetus. This case highlights the importance of genetic counseling and screening prior to IVF treatment, especially in patients with a history of recurrent miscarriages. It also adds to the existing body of literature on the potential risks associated with cryopreserved embryo transfer. Further research is warranted to investigate the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions to reduce the risk of genetic abnormalities in IVF pregnancies.

Use of Mohs micrographic surgery to establish quantitative proof of heightened tumor spread in basal cell carcinoma recurrent following radiotherapy. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer, and recurrence following radiotherapy is not uncommon. However, the true extent of tumor spread in recurrent BCC following radiotherapy remains uncertain. This study aimed to utilize Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) to establish quantitative proof of heightened tumor spread in recurrent BCC after radiotherapy. A retrospective analysis of 25 patients with recurrent BCC after radiotherapy who underwent MMS was conducted. The study found that MMS revealed a significantly larger tumor size and increased resection area compared to initial diagnosis and treatment. Moreover, a significant correlation was observed between the duration of radiotherapy and the size of the recurrent BCC. These findings suggest that recurrent BCC following radiotherapy is associated with a higher risk of tumor spread and supports the use of MMS as a valuable tool for accurate assessment and treatment of recurrent BCC post-radiotherapy. Further studies are warranted to explore additional factors influencing tumor spread in recurrent BCC.

Critical review of gangliosides and thyrotropin-releasing hormone in peripheral neuromuscular diseases. OBJECTIVE: To critically review the efficacy and potential use of gangliosides and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) in the treatment of peripheral neuromuscular diseases.

METHODS: A comprehensive literature search was conducted using relevant databases including PubMed and Google Scholar. Studies investigating the effects of gangliosides and TRH in peripheral neuromuscular diseases were reviewed. Key outcomes of interest included muscle strength, nerve conduction velocity, and functional outcomes.

RESULTS: Gangliosides have shown promise in improving muscle strength and nerve conduction velocity in various peripheral neuropathies. However, the evidence regarding their efficacy in other peripheral neuromuscular diseases is limited. TRH, on the other hand, has been found to enhance muscle strength and improve functional outcomes in patients with myasthenia gravis and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. However, further research is needed to determine its potential benefits in other peripheral neuromuscular diseases.

CONCLUSION: Gangliosides and TRH hold potential as treatment options for peripheral neuromuscular diseases. However, the current evidence is limited and further well-designed studies are warranted to establish their efficacy and safety profiles.

Sensitivity for detecting fibrillation potentials: a comparison between concentric and monopolar needle electrodes.  The sensitivity of monopolar and concentric electrodes for detecting fibrillation potentials (FP) has never been formally compared. This study aimed to compare the sensitivity of monopolar and concentric needle electrodes in detecting fibrillation potentials (FP). A total of 50 patients with known FP were included in the study. Each patient underwent electromyography (EMG) using both monopolar and concentric electrodes. The FP detection rate was then recorded for each electrode type. The results showed that the sensitivity of monopolar electrodes in detecting FP was significantly higher compared to concentric electrodes (p<0.001). This suggests that monopolar electrodes may be more effective in detecting FP during EMG procedures. Further research is warranted to investigate the clinical implications of these findings in the diagnosis and management of neuromuscular disorders.

Scrotal inflammatory disease: color Doppler US findings. Part III. A retrospective study. A retrospective study of 58 patients with suspected scrotal inflammatory disease who underwent color Doppler ultrasonography (US) was conducted. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the color Doppler US findings in scrotal inflammatory disease cases. The patients' age at the time of examination, presenting symptoms, physical findings, color Doppler US findings, and final diagnosis were analyzed. The most common presenting symptom was scrotal pain and the most common physical finding was scrotal swelling. Color Doppler US findings revealed increased vascularity in the scrotal wall, epididymis, and testis, indicative of inflammatory changes. Other findings included hypoechoic heterogeneous areas and increased intratesticular blood flow. The final diagnosis varied and included orchitis, epididymitis, and abscess formation. The sensitivity of color Doppler US in detecting scrotal inflammatory disease was 93.1%, with a specificity of 93.8%. In conclusion, color Doppler US is a valuable tool in the diagnosis of scrotal inflammatory disease, providing detailed information about blood flow and aiding in appropriate and timely management.

Multiple cranial nerve deficits after ethylene glycol poisoning.  We report the cases of two patients who developed cranial nerve palsies after drinking ethylene glycol. Ethylene glycol poisoning is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that can lead to neurological complications. We present the cases of two patients who experienced multiple cranial nerve deficits after ingesting ethylene glycol. Both patients presented with visual disturbances, diplopia, dysphagia, and dysarthria. Neurological examination revealed cranial nerve palsies, including involvement of the oculomotor, trochlear, trigeminal, facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves. Laboratory investigations confirmed the presence of ethylene glycol in their blood samples. Prompt initiation of treatment with ethanol and hemodialysis resulted in partial recovery of cranial nerve function in both patients. This case series highlights the importance of considering ethylene glycol poisoning as a potential etiology in patients presenting with multiple cranial nerve deficits, especially in the context of a history of substance abuse or accidental ingestion. Early recognition and intervention are crucial in maximizing functional outcomes in these patients.

Manometric evaluation of jejunal limb after total gastrectomy and Roux-Orr anastomosis for gastric cancer. Total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction is a common surgical procedure for gastric cancer. However, little is known about the functional outcomes of the jejunal limb after this procedure. This study aimed to evaluate the motility of the jejunal limb using manometry. Twelve patients who underwent total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction were included in the study. Manometric evaluation was performed at 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively. The findings revealed that the jejunal limb had decreased motility compared to the preoperative state. Additionally, abnormalities in contractile patterns were observed, including decreased tone and impaired peristaltic activity. These abnormalities persisted up to 12 months after surgery. These findings suggest that postoperative jejunal motility is compromised following total gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction. Further research is needed to determine the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions to improve postoperative jejunum function in these patients.

Death by smothering and its investigation. This study aimed to investigate the characteristics and forensic investigation of death by smothering. Autopsy records from a forensic pathology department were reviewed from 2000 to 2010, identifying 34 cases of death by smothering. The majority of victims were infants (n=23) and the remaining cases involved adults (n=11). Smothering was mostly inflicted in a domestic setting and the perpetrators were usually family members or caregivers. The cause of death was asphyxia due to obstruction of the airway. Signs of struggle and the presence of physical injuries were commonly observed. Understanding the forensic features of death by smothering is crucial for accurate determination of cause and manner of death.

Infertility and eating disorders.  Sixty-six consecutive infertility clinic patients were prospectively screened with the 26-item Eating Attitudes Test and a study questionnaire. Results showed that 25% of the patients scored above the cutoff for high risk of disordered eating. This subgroup of patients had significantly higher levels of distress and depression compared to patients with no disordered eating. They also reported more body image dissatisfaction and lower self-esteem. Patients with disordered eating were more likely to have a history of dieting, engage in excessive exercise, and have greater concerns about their weight and shape. These findings suggest that there is a significant overlap between infertility and eating disorders, with a substantial proportion of infertility patients at risk for disordered eating. It is important for healthcare professionals to screen for and address these issues in order to provide comprehensive care for infertility patients. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop appropriate interventions.

Intrahepatic lymphatics opacified during hepatic arteriography in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma. A rare case of intrahepatic lymphatics opacification during hepatic arteriography in a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma is presented. The patient, a 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis, underwent hepatic arteriography for evaluation of a hepatic mass. Unexpectedly, the lymphatic channels within the liver were visualized during the procedure. This finding has not been previously reported in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. The opacification of lymphatics was confirmed by repeat imaging and was attributed to lymphatic metastasis from the tumor. This case highlights the potential role of lymphatic involvement in the spread of hepatocellular carcinoma and emphasizes the importance of thorough evaluation during diagnostic procedures. Further studies are warranted to elucidate the significance of intrahepatic lymphatic opacification in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in multiple endocrine neoplasia. Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy (CIC) is a rare but severe manifestation in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN). In this retrospective study, we aimed to assess the clinical characteristics, management, and outcomes of patients with CIC associated with MEN. A total of 15 patients with CIC and MEN were included, and their medical records were reviewed. The majority of patients presented with symptoms of heart failure, including dyspnea and fatigue. Echocardiography revealed severe left ventricular dysfunction. Treatment strategies included volume overload reduction, beta-blocker therapy, and tumor resection when feasible. Despite aggressive management, the overall prognosis was poor, with a high mortality rate observed within a 1-year follow-up period. Further research is warranted to explore optimal treatment strategies and improve outcomes in this challenging patient population.

Chronic rupture of the Achilles tendon: a new technique of repair. Chronic rupture of the Achilles tendon is a debilitating condition that requires surgical intervention for optimal outcomes. This report presents a novel technique of repair for chronic Achilles tendon rupture utilizing a free hamstring graft. A retrospective analysis of ten patients who underwent this technique was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the procedure. All patients achieved satisfactory clinical outcomes with significant improvements in pain, range of motion, and functional ability. Radiographic assessment revealed excellent graft incorporation and restoration of tendon continuity. Complications were minimal, with only one case of superficial wound infection that resolved with conservative management. The proposed technique offers several advantages, including a reliable and easily accessible graft source, minimal donor site morbidity, and improved biomechanical properties for optimal tendon healing. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings and establish the long-term efficacy of this technique.

Clinical judgments in pain management. Effective pain management is crucial in improving patient outcomes and satisfaction. However, clinical judgments regarding pain management can be challenging, as pain is subjective and multifaceted. This study aims to analyze the clinical judgments of healthcare providers in pain management. A systematic review was conducted on various databases, including PubMed and Scopus, to identify relevant studies published between 2010 and 2021. The findings revealed several factors influencing clinical judgments, such as patients' self-report, non-verbal cues, and contextual information. Additionally, healthcare providers' knowledge, experience, and biases played a significant role. Various tools and guidelines were utilized to assist in making informed clinical judgments. Further research is needed to develop standardized approaches and training programs to enhance accurate and effective pain management within diverse healthcare settings. By improving clinical judgments in pain management, healthcare providers can optimize patient care and outcomes.

Incarceration of colonoscope in an inguinal hernia. We present a case report of an unusual complication following colonoscopy, where the colonoscope became incarcerated in an inguinal hernia. A 62-year-old male with a known inguinal hernia presented for a routine colonoscopy. During the procedure, the colonoscope was inserted without difficulty until it reached the transverse colon. However, upon attempted withdrawal, the scope became lodged in the inguinal hernia, causing significant pain and discomfort. Immediate intervention was required, and the patient underwent an emergency surgical repair of the hernia with successful removal of the colonoscope. This case highlights the importance of recognizing potential complications during colonoscopy and the need for prompt intervention to prevent further complications or injuries in patients with known hernias.

Doppler ultrasonography of malignant melanomas of the uvea.  Doppler shifts were detected using duplex and color Doppler scanning in 41 of 42 patients with malignant melanomas of the uvea. This study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of Doppler ultrasonography in detecting malignant melanomas of the uvea. Duplex and color Doppler scanning were performed on 42 patients with confirmed uveal melanomas. Doppler shifts were successfully detected in 41 out of the 42 patients, indicating the presence of blood flow within the melanomas. The Doppler technique was particularly effective in identifying the vascularity and vascular patterns of the tumors. This information is crucial for determining the stage and prognosis of uveal melanomas. Doppler ultrasonography provides a non-invasive and reliable method for assessing the blood flow within uveal melanomas, offering valuable diagnostic and prognostic information. Further studies are warranted to explore the potential of this imaging technique in guiding treatment decisions and monitoring the response to therapy in patients with uveal melanomas.

Primary intramedullary nailing of open femoral shaft fractures.  The cases of 60 patients with 63 open femoral fractures treated by primary reamed intramedullary nailing were retrospectively reviewed. The purpose of this retrospective study was to assess the outcomes of primary reamed intramedullary nailing in the treatment of open femoral shaft fractures. A total of 60 patients with 63 open femoral fractures were included in the study. The fractures were classified according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification system. All patients underwent primary reamed intramedullary nailing within 24 hours of admission. The mean follow-up period was 12 months.

The results showed that the union rate was 96.8%, with a mean time to union of 19.5 weeks. The infection rate was 6.3%, and the nonunion rate was 3.2%. Complications such as implant failure, malunion, and deep vein thrombosis were observed in a small number of cases. The functional outcomes, as assessed by the modified Harris Hip Score, were satisfactory in the majority of patients.

In conclusion, primary reamed intramedullary nailing is an effective treatment option for open femoral shaft fractures, with high union rates and satisfactory functional outcomes. However, the risk of infection should be considered, and close follow-up is necessary to detect and manage complications.

Clinical results of axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene Seventy-six axillobifemoral grafts with externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene prostheses were performed since 1983. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the clinical outcomes of axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) prostheses. A total of 76 procedures were performed from 1983 to present, with a mean follow-up of 5 years. Primary patency rates were assessed using Kaplan-Meier analysis, and secondary patency rates were assessed using cumulative incidence analysis. The results showed an overall primary patency rate of 85% at 5 years, with a secondary patency rate of 94% at the same time point. These findings suggest that axillobifemoral bypass with externally supported PTFE prostheses is a successful and durable treatment option for patients with aortoiliac occlusive disease.

Hypertension and acculturation in elderly Mexican Americans: results from 1982-84 Hispanic HANES. This study aimed to examine the association between acculturation and hypertension prevalence in elderly Mexican Americans. Data from the 1982-84 Hispanic Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (HANES) were analyzed, focusing on individuals aged 65 and older. Acculturation was measured using various indicators, including language preference and years of residence in the United States. Hypertension was defined as systolic blood pressure of 140 mmHg or higher, diastolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg or higher, or current use of antihypertensive medication. After adjusting for age, sex, education, income, and body mass index, the study found that higher acculturation levels were associated with an increased prevalence of hypertension. Specifically, individuals who preferred speaking English and had longer durations of residence in the US were more likely to have hypertension.
