These findings highlight the need for culturally tailored interventions and healthcare strategies to address the unique health challenges faced by elderly Mexican Americans.

Role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium. Ischemic heart disease remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Reperfusion therapy, such as thrombolytic therapy or percutaneous coronary intervention, has significantly improved outcomes in patients with acute myocardial infarction. However, paradoxically, reperfusion itself may induce additional injury to the myocardium, known as reperfusion injury. This phenomenon is characterized by a cascade of events involving the production of oxygen free radicals.

Oxygen free radicals are highly reactive molecules that can cause cellular damage by initiating lipid peroxidation, protein oxidation, DNA damage, and activation of inflammatory pathways. In the setting of ischemia and subsequent reperfusion, an excess of oxygen free radicals is generated due to the increased availability of molecular oxygen.

Several mechanisms contribute to the generation of oxygen free radicals during reperfusion, including mitochondrial dysfunction, activation of xanthine oxidase, and activation of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase. These reactive species not only directly damage cellular components but also contribute to the recruitment and activation of inflammatory cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages.

Growing evidence suggests that oxygen free radicals play a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of reperfusion injury. Numerous experimental studies have demonstrated that interventions aimed at reducing oxygen free radicals, such as antioxidant therapy and inhibition of NADPH oxidase, can attenuate reperfusion injury and improve myocardial salvage.

In conclusion, reperfusion injury represents an important clinical challenge in the management of patients with acute myocardial infarction. Oxygen free radicals contribute significantly to the pathogenesis of reperfusion injury, and targeting these reactive species holds promise for mitigating myocardial damage and improving patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to delineate the precise mechanisms underlying reperfusion injury and to identify novel therapeutic targets for this debilitating condition.

The human costs of cancer and the response of the National Cancer Program. This study aims to assess the human costs of cancer and the effectiveness of the National Cancer Program in addressing these costs. A total of 87 cancer patients were enrolled in the study and divided into two groups based on their participation in the National Cancer Program. The first group consisted of 42 patients who had actively engaged in the program, while the second group included 45 patients who did not participate. The results showed that the patients who participated in the program had significantly lower emotional distress, higher quality of life, and better access to healthcare services compared to those who did not participate. These findings suggest that the National Cancer Program plays a pivotal role in alleviating the human costs of cancer and improving patient outcomes.

Femur fracture with limb shortening causing occlusion of a polytetrafluoroethylene femoral popliteal graft. We present a case of a femur fracture with limb shortening leading to occlusion of a polytetrafluoroethylene femoral popliteal graft in a 62-year-old male. The patient had a history of peripheral arterial disease and underwent a femoral popliteal bypass surgery using a polytetrafluoroethylene graft. However, three months post-surgery, he sustained a femur fracture due to a fall, resulting in limb shortening. Subsequently, the graft became compressed, leading to complete occlusion and ischemia of the lower limb. This case highlights the importance of considering limb length and fracture stability when assessing the suitability of vascular grafting in patients with peripheral arterial disease. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial to prevent graft occlusion and limb ischemia.

Cardiac pathology in 470 consecutive forensic autopsies.  Cardiovascular disease continues to be the single most common generic cause of sudden and unexpected deaths. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 470 consecutive forensic autopsies to investigate the cardiac pathology in cases of sudden and unexpected deaths. The study found that cardiovascular disease remained the most prevalent generic cause of such deaths. In total, 53% of the cases exhibited signs of cardiac pathology, with atherosclerosis being the most frequently observed condition (31% of cases). Myocardial infarction was identified in 17% of cases, followed by cardiomyopathy in 13% and valvular heart disease in 8%. Interestingly, structural abnormalities such as ventricular hypertrophy and dilatation were also present in a significant proportion of cases (14%). This study underscores the continued importance of cardiovascular disease as a leading cause of sudden and unexpected deaths, necessitating thorough investigation and prevention strategies.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. The purpose of this study was to analyze the findings of 1000 consecutive autopsies conducted by a medical examiner in order to gain insight into the concept of natural death. The majority of the autopsies (85%) were performed on individuals who had died from cardiovascular diseases, followed by neoplastic diseases (7%) and respiratory diseases (5%). The most common cause of death within these categories was coronary artery disease. It was found that 89% of the autopsies revealed significant findings that were not previously known to the attending physicians. These findings included myocardial infarction, advanced cancer, and pulmonary embolism, among others. The study highlights the importance of autopsies in understanding the true nature of natural deaths and improving diagnostic accuracy.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. A case report of a 58-year-old man presenting with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort is described. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the biliary tract, leading to a diagnosis of malignant melanoma. The patient underwent surgical resection, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma involving the biliary tract. Immunohistochemical staining showed positive staining for Melan-A and HMB-45, consistent with melanocytic origin. Given the rarity of malignant melanoma involving the biliary tract, a thorough investigation for primary melanoma in other sites was conducted, but no primary lesion was identified. This case highlights the importance of considering malignant melanoma in the differential diagnosis of biliary tract malignancies and the challenges in managing this aggressive tumor.

Bladder function in the mentally retarded. Bladder dysfunction is a common problem in individuals with mental retardation. However, little is known about the underlying mechanisms and factors contributing to this impairment. This study aimed to evaluate the bladder function in mentally retarded individuals and identify potential associations with specific cognitive impairments. A total of 50 mentally retarded individuals were included in the study, and their bladder function was assessed using urodynamic testing. Cognitive function was evaluated using standardized tests. Results showed a high prevalence of bladder dysfunction in the study population, with detrusor overactivity being the most common finding. Furthermore, specific cognitive impairments, such as impaired executive function and poor attention span, were associated with more severe bladder dysfunction. These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to address bladder dysfunction in mentally retarded individuals, taking into account their specific cognitive impairments.

Immunophenotyping in the management of gastric lymphoma.  Primary gastric lymphoma is a rare tumor in which surgical resection plays a major role in improving the response rate and reducing the incidence of bleeding and perforation after chemotherapy. Immunohistochemical analysis of gastric lymphoma is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management. This study aimed to investigate the utility of immunophenotyping in the management of gastric lymphoma. A total of 42 patients with gastric lymphoma were included in the study. Immunohistochemistry was performed using a panel of antibodies including CD20, CD3, CD5, CD10, and cyclin D1. The results showed that the majority of cases were classified as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (n=28), followed by mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma (n=9) and follicular lymphoma (FL) (n=5). Immunophenotyping revealed that CD20 was positive in all cases of DLBCL and FL, while CD3 and CD5 were negative. CD10 expression was observed in a subset of DLBCL cases. MALT lymphomas showed CD20 and cyclin D1 negativity but were positive for CD3. These findings highlight the importance of immunophenotyping in the diagnosis and management of gastric lymphoma, helping to guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes.

Dapsone is an effective therapy for the skin lesions of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and urticarial vasculitis in a patient with C2 deficiency. A 35-year-old woman with a known history of C2 deficiency presented with skin lesions consistent with subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and urticarial vasculitis. Treatment options were limited due to her immune deficiency and previous lack of response to standard therapies. However, she was initiated on dapsone, a potent anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidant drug. After two months of therapy, a significant improvement in her skin lesions was observed, along with resolution of pruritus and erythema. Laboratory investigations showed a normalization of inflammatory markers, and a subsequent skin biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of both subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and urticarial vasculitis. Dapsone was continued as maintenance therapy, and the patient remained asymptomatic and without any signs of disease exacerbation during two years of follow-up. Dapsone may represent a viable therapeutic option in patients with C2 deficiency and skin manifestations of autoimmune diseases.

Gastric lesions secondary to long-distance running.  Gastrointestinal disorders have been reported during long-distance running. These disorders can manifest as gastric lesions, which are erosions or ulcers that develop in the stomach lining. The exact mechanisms for the development of gastric lesions during long-distance running are not fully understood, but they are believed to be multifactorial. Factors that may contribute to their development include physical stress on the gastrointestinal tract, changes in blood flow and oxygen delivery to the stomach, increased levels of stress hormones, altered gastric motility, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug use. Furthermore, dehydration and inadequate nutrition during prolonged exercise may also play a role. It is important for athletes and medical professionals to be aware of these potential complications and take necessary precautions to prevent and manage them. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management strategies for gastric lesions associated with long-distance running.

Neuroendocrine carcinoid tumours of the breast: a variant of carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. Neuroendocrine carcinoid tumors of the breast are a rare variant of breast carcinoma characterized by neuroendocrine differentiation. These tumors account for less than 1% of all breast carcinomas and have distinct clinicopathological features. This abstract aims to summarize the current knowledge on neuroendocrine carcinoid tumors of the breast. 

Histologically, these tumors display neuroendocrine features, such as nested and trabecular growth patterns, characteristic chromogranin A and synaptophysin immunohistochemistry, and neurosecretory granules. They are typically estrogen and progesterone receptor positive and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) negative. 

Clinical presentation is variable, with most patients presenting with a palpable mass. Imaging modalities, such as mammography and ultrasound, may show suspicious findings, but a definitive diagnosis relies on histopathological examination. The prognosis of neuroendocrine carcinoid tumors of the breast is favorable, with a low risk of lymph node metastasis and a good response to hormonal therapy. 

Further research is needed to better understand the molecular characteristics and optimal management of these rare breast tumors.

The risk of large bowel cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease.  The relative risk (standardized incidence ratio [SIR] for colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease was examined in a population-based cohort comprising 6459 patients operated during 1950 to 1958.  Follow-up through 1983 revealed 131 cases of colorectal cancer versus 150. The risk of developing colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease was investigated in a population-based cohort study. The study included 6459 patients who underwent partial gastrectomy between 1950 and 1958. The patients were followed up until 1983, during which 131 cases of colorectal cancer were identified. The standardized incidence ratio (SIR) was calculated to determine the relative risk of developing colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy. The SIR for colorectal cancer in this cohort was found to be 0.87 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.73-1.02), indicating that there was no significant increase in the risk of developing colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease. These findings suggest that partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease does not substantially increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer.

Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty with a cemented long-stem component. Cardiac arrest is a rare but life-threatening complication that can occur during hip arthroplasty with a cemented long-stem component. This case report describes a 62-year-old male patient who experienced sudden cardiac arrest during surgery. Despite immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation, the patient remained hemodynamically unstable.

Several potential factors contributed to the cardiac arrest, including preexisting coronary artery disease, arrhythmias, and the surgical procedure itself. However, the most likely cause was a cement embolism, as evidenced by the sudden onset of hypotension and oxygen desaturation, along with the absence of other identifiable causes.

Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty is a rare but devastating complication that requires prompt recognition and intervention. Surgeons should be aware of the possibility of cement embolism and use preventive measures, such as meticulous cementing technique and proper positioning of the components, to minimize the risk. Furthermore, a high level of preparedness and coordinated efforts between the surgical and anesthesia teams are crucial for managing such emergencies effectively and improving patient outcomes.

Early magnetic resonance imaging in acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a rare ocular motility disorder characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement due to dysfunction of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). We present a case report of a 47-year-old female who presented with acute traumatic INO following a motor vehicle accident. Early magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed hyperintensity in the left MLF, confirming the diagnosis of traumatic INO. The patient was managed conservatively, and her symptoms resolved within six weeks. This case highlights the importance of early recognition and diagnosis of traumatic INO using MRI, which can aid in appropriate management and prognosis for these patients. Further research is needed to explore the long-term outcomes and treatment strategies for traumatic INO.

A study of the comparative efficacy of four common analgesics in the control of postsurgical dental pain. A randomized controlled trial was conducted to compare the efficacy of four common analgesics in controlling postsurgical dental pain. A total of 120 patients who underwent dental surgery were randomly assigned to receive one of four analgesics: ibuprofen, acetaminophen, naproxen, or codeine. Pain scores were assessed at intervals of 1, 2, 4, and 6 hours after surgery using a visual analog scale. Results showed that all four analgesics provided significant pain relief compared to baseline, with ibuprofen demonstrating the fastest onset of action and highest overall efficacy. No significant differences were observed in adverse effects among the groups. This study provides valuable information for clinicians in selecting appropriate analgesics for postsurgical dental pain management.

Partial duplication of the face: case report and review. Partial duplication of the face is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of an additional facial structure. We present a case report of a 5-year-old male with a partial duplication of the face involving the left cheek and mandible. The duplicated structure had its own set of facial features, including an eye and ear, and was accompanied by hypertrophy and malformation of adjacent facial structures. Literature review identified only a limited number of similar cases, highlighting the unique nature of this anomaly. The etiology of partial duplication of the face remains unclear, although it is believed to result from abnormal facial development during embryogenesis. Management of this condition often involves surgical intervention to address functional and aesthetic concerns. Increased awareness and early diagnosis of this rare anomaly are crucial for appropriate management and optimal outcomes.

Tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome Eight patients who became ill while taking tryptophan had myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. Between 1989 and 1990, eight patients presented with symptoms consistent with eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) after consuming tryptophan supplements. The clinical manifestations included myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. Laboratory investigations revealed marked eosinophilia in all patients. Prior to the onset of symptoms, the patients had been taking different brands of tryptophan supplements for an average of three months. All patients responded to the discontinuation of tryptophan and supportive care. This case series highlights the potential risk of tryptophan-induced EMS and the importance of considering this diagnosis in patients presenting with characteristic symptoms.

Amiloride blocks the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in the sheep. Hypertension induced by ACTH administration has been widely studied in animal models. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) has been implicated as a key player in the development of ACTH-induced hypertension. The aldosterone antagonist, amiloride, has been found to have inhibitory effects on the RAAS. In this study, we investigate the potential of amiloride to block the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep. Ten sheep were divided into two groups, with one group receiving ACTH alone and the other receiving ACTH in combination with amiloride. Blood pressure was measured before and after treatment, and plasma renin activity and aldosterone levels were assessed. Our results demonstrate that amiloride effectively blocked the development of hypertension induced by ACTH administration in sheep. These findings suggest a potential therapeutic role for amiloride in the management of ACTH-induced hypertension in humans, warranting further investigation.

Imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters using transvaginal sonography. Transvaginal sonography (TVS) has emerged as a valuable tool for imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy due to its high resolution and ability to provide real-time imaging. This study aimed to assess the feasibility and diagnostic accuracy of TVS for visualizing the fetal brain during this period. A total of 100 pregnant women with gestational ages ranging from 16 to 32 weeks underwent TVS to evaluate fetal brain structures. All images were reviewed by experienced sonographers and compared with postnatal imaging or clinical follow-up. TVS demonstrated good visualization of the key anatomical structures of the fetal brain, including the ventricles, cortex, cerebellum, and midbrain. In cases where abnormalities were detected, TVS accurately predicted the final diagnosis in 90% of cases. The findings highlight the potential of TVS as a reliable and non-invasive method for evaluating the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions are rare benign conditions that can affect the head and neck region. This study aims to describe the clinical and pathological features of these lesions and discuss their management. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients with histologically confirmed tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions in the head and neck. The study included 27 patients, of whom the majority were middle-aged females. The most common presenting symptom was a painless mass, and the most frequent anatomical location was the parotid gland. Pathological examination revealed a fibroinflammatory infiltrate with varying degrees of fibrosis. Surgical excision was the mainstay of treatment, with good outcomes observed in the majority of cases. Awareness of tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management of these uncommon entities in the head and neck region.

Isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary fibrosis is a debilitating disease characterized by progressive scarring of lung tissue, resulting in impaired respiratory function. Isolated lung transplantation has emerged as a viable treatment option for end-stage pulmonary fibrosis. In a retrospective study of 56 patients who underwent isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis, the overall survival rate was 74.6% at 1 year and 56.6% at 5 years. The most common indication for transplantation was idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Post-transplant complications included acute rejection (46.4%), infection (42.9%), and bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (32.1%). Improved lung function was observed post-transplant, with the mean forced expiratory volume in 1 second increasing from 27.5% pre-transplant to 71.2% at 1 year. Isolated lung transplantation provides a promising treatment option for patients with end-stage pulmonary fibrosis, improving survival rates and lung function. However, careful patient selection and long-term monitoring are essential for optimal outcomes.

Empiric treatment of fungal infections in the neutropenic host. Neutropenic patients are particularly susceptible to invasive fungal infections due to their compromised immune system. Empiric treatment of these infections is of utmost importance to prevent morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of empiric antifungal therapy in neutropenic hosts. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 neutropenic patients who received empiric antifungal treatment between January 2015 and December 2017. The most commonly prescribed antifungal agents were fluconazole (47%), voriconazole (31%), and caspofungin (21%). The overall response rate to empiric antifungal therapy was 76%, with complete resolution of symptoms and negative fungal cultures. However, 24% of patients experienced treatment failure, with persistent or worsening symptoms and positive fungal cultures. Adverse events were reported in 13% of patients, most commonly gastrointestinal disturbances and hepatotoxicity. This study highlights the importance of empiric antifungal therapy in neutropenic patients and the need for proper selection of antifungal agents based on local epidemiology and susceptibility patterns. Future studies are warranted to optimize treatment strategies and minimize adverse events in this vulnerable patient population.

Association of Treacher Collins syndrome and translocation 6p21. 31/16p13. 11: exclusion of the locus from these candidate regions. Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by craniofacial malformations. While there have been several reports suggesting a genetic basis for TCS, the exact etiology remains elusive. In this study, we aimed to investigate the association between TCS and two candidate regions, namely translocation 6p21.31 and 16p13.11. 
A total of 20 patients with confirmed TCS diagnosis were enrolled in the study. Chromosomal microarray analysis was performed to identify any genetic aberrations within these candidate regions. Surprisingly, none of the patients showed any translocation involving 6p21.31 or 16p13.11. This suggests that these candidate regions are not involved in the pathogenesis of TCS in this cohort. 
The identification of the genetic basis of TCS is crucial for accurate diagnosis, genetic counseling, and potential therapeutic interventions. Our findings highlight the necessity of further research to identify novel candidate genes and regions associated with TCS.

The role of antihistamine therapy in vascular headaches. Vascular headaches, such as migraines and cluster headaches, are often debilitating conditions that greatly impact the quality of life for many individuals. Antihistamine therapy has been investigated as a potential treatment option for these types of headaches due to its ability to modulate the dilation and constriction of blood vessels. This medical abstract aims to evaluate the role of antihistamine therapy in the management of vascular headaches. A systematic review of the available literature was conducted, which included randomized controlled trials and observational studies. The results indicate that antihistamine therapy may provide some relief for vascular headaches, particularly in reducing the severity and frequency of migraine attacks. However, further research is needed to elucidate the optimal dosage, duration of treatment, and potential side effects of antihistamine therapy in this patient population. Overall, antihistamine therapy shows promise as an adjunctive treatment for vascular headaches, but more studies are required to establish its efficacy and safety.

The value of push-type jejunal endoscopy in familial adenomatosis coli/Gardner's syndrome. Familial adenomatosis coli (FAC) or Gardner's syndrome is a hereditary disorder characterized by the development of multiple colorectal adenomas. Push-type jejunal endoscopy has emerged as a valuable tool for the detection and surveillance of jejunal polyps in these patients. In this study, we evaluated the utility of push-type jejunal endoscopy in 36 patients with FAC/Gardner's syndrome. The endoscopic findings were correlated with histopathological examination of the resected polyps. Push-type jejunal endoscopy detected jejunal polyps in 32 out of 36 patients (88.9%). The polyps were predominantly located in the proximal jejunum. Histopathological analysis revealed a variety of polyp types, including adenomas and hamartomas. Importantly, push-type jejunal endoscopy identified seven patients with advanced adenomas, facilitating early intervention and reducing the risk of malignant transformation. Our findings demonstrate the value of push-type jejunal endoscopy as an effective modality for the detection and management of jejunal polyps in patients with FAC/Gardner's syndrome.

Uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. Angelman's syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability, developmental delay, speech impairment, and a unique behavioral phenotype. The majority of cases are caused by a deletion or mutation in the maternally inherited chromosome 15q11-q13 region. However, approximately 5-7% of cases result from uniparental paternal disomy (UPD), in which both copies of chromosome 15 are inherited from the father. This abnormality disrupts the imprinting process that normally occurs in this region and leads to the loss of expression of the UBE3A gene, which is critical for normal brain development. UPD can be detected through genetic testing, specifically through methylation analysis or chromosomal microarray analysis. Understanding the underlying genetic mechanisms of Angelman's syndrome, including UPD, is important for accurate diagnosis and management of affected individuals.

Primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in advanced prostatic cancer--a randomized study: results after 7 to 10 years of followup. In this randomized study, the efficacy of primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer was evaluated over a 7 to 10-year follow-up period. A total of 156 male patients with advanced prostatic cancer were enrolled and randomized into two groups: one group underwent primary orchiectomy, while the other group received estrogen therapy. 

The results of this study showed that both treatment modalities demonstrated comparable efficacy in terms of overall survival rates, disease-free intervals, and symptomatic relief. However, patients in the orchiectomy group experienced a higher incidence of adverse effects, such as hot flashes, impotence, and decreased libido, compared to those in the estrogen therapy group.

These findings suggest that estrogen therapy could be considered as an alternative to primary orchiectomy in the treatment of advanced prostatic cancer, providing similar benefits in terms of survival and symptom control while potentially minimizing certain side effects. Further long-term studies are warranted to confirm and strengthen these results.

CD34 antigen expression in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This study aimed to investigate the expression of CD34 antigen in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph+ ALL). A total of 146 children diagnosed with Ph+ ALL were enrolled in the study. Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to detect the presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene. Flow cytometry analysis was performed to evaluate the expression of CD34 antigen on leukemic cells. The results showed that 86% of the patients expressed the CD34 antigen on leukemic cells. Moreover, the expression of CD34 antigen was significantly associated with older age at diagnosis and higher white blood cell count. Interestingly, CD34 antigen expression was also correlated with worse overall survival and event-free survival in these patients. These findings suggest that CD34 antigen expression may serve as a prognostic marker in pediatric patients with Ph+ ALL, allowing for more accurate risk stratification and targeted therapeutic approaches.

Transient entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve in violin players. Violin players are susceptible to entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), causing pain and weakness in the forearm and hand. This study aimed to assess the prevalence and risk factors of PIN entrapment in violin players. Sixteen violin players diagnosed with PIN entrapment neuropathy were included. Results showed that the duration of violin play, weekly practice hours, and improper technique were significant risk factors for developing PIN entrapment. The most common symptoms reported were pain, weakness, and difficulty in finger movements. It is crucial for clinicians to be aware of this condition and its risk factors in order to provide timely diagnosis and appropriate management to violin players.

Ondansetron: a new entity in emesis control. Ondansetron is a potent and highly selective serotonin receptor antagonist that has proven to be a valuable tool in the management of nausea and vomiting in various clinical settings. Initially approved for use in chemotherapy-induced emesis control, ondansetron has since shown efficacy in other types of nausea and vomiting, including postoperative, radiation-induced, and pregnancy-related. This abstract presents a comprehensive review of the pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, and clinical applications of ondansetron. The mechanisms of action of ondansetron, including its ability to block serotonin receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system, are discussed. Furthermore, the dosing regimens and potential adverse effects of ondansetron are addressed. The emerging research on extended-release formulations and combination therapies involving ondansetron is also highlighted. Overall, ondansetron represents a promising tool in the management of emesis, with a well-established safety profile and broad applicability across different patient populations.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Vitamin E has been reported to possess antioxidant properties and may serve as a protective agent in various biological systems. In this study, we investigated the potential protective role of vitamin E against oxidative damage in different cellular and organ systems. We reviewed studies on the effects of vitamin E supplementation in animal models, human patients, and in vitro cell culture systems. The results consistently showed that vitamin E supplementation can attenuate oxidative stress and prevent cellular damage. Furthermore, vitamin E was found to exert its protective effects through multiple mechanisms, including scavenging of reactive oxygen species, inhibition of lipid peroxidation, modulation of antioxidant enzyme activity, and modulation of cell signaling pathways. These findings highlight the potential therapeutic applications of vitamin E in preventing or treating various oxidative stress-related diseases.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a chronic immune-mediated disorder affecting the peripheral nerves. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) has been shown to be an effective treatment option for CIDP. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of IVIG treatment in patients with CIDP. 
A retrospective analysis was performed on patients diagnosed with CIDP who received IVIG treatment at a tertiary hospital over a 5-year period. The primary outcome measure was the change in the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score, a measure of functional disability, before and after IVIG treatment. Secondary outcomes included improvements in muscle strength, sensory function, and quality of life.
Results showed that IVIG treatment led to significant improvements in mRS scores (p<0.001), muscle strength (p<0.001), and sensory function (p<0.001) compared to baseline. The majority of patients also reported improvements in quality of life. IVIG treatment was well-tolerated, with no serious adverse events reported.
In conclusion, IVIG treatment is an effective and safe therapeutic option for patients with CIDP. Further studies are warranted to optimize treatment regimens and identify predictors of response to IVIG in this patient population.

Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy. Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy have emerged as potential options for patients who are not suitable candidates for surgery or who prefer non-surgical approaches. These alternatives aim to treat gallbladder diseases such as cholecystitis and choledocholithiasis while minimizing invasiveness and improving patient outcomes. This review article summarizes the current evidence on three interventional radiologic procedures: percutaneous cholecystostomy, endoscopic transpapillary gallbladder drainage, and percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage. Each procedure involves image-guided placement of catheters or stents to allow drainage of the gallbladder or common bile duct. The efficacy and safety of these interventions are discussed, along with patient selection criteria and potential complications. While there is limited data available, these interventional radiologic alternatives may provide valuable options for patients who are high-risk surgical candidates or who prefer non-surgical management. Further research is warranted to validate and expand the use of these procedures in clinical practice.

Short-term memory and sentence comprehension. Short-term memory and sentence comprehension are crucial cognitive processes for communication and daily functioning. However, the relationship between these two processes is not well understood. This study aims to investigate the impact of short-term memory capacity on sentence comprehension abilities. Participants were asked to engage in a sentence comprehension task while their short-term memory capacity was assessed using various tasks. Results showed a significant correlation between short-term memory capacity and sentence comprehension performance. Individuals with higher short-term memory capacity demonstrated greater accuracy and faster response times in understanding and processing sentences. Moreover, the findings revealed that working memory plays a crucial role in sentence comprehension, particularly in complex sentence structures. These findings have important implications for understanding and improving communication and language skills in individuals with compromised short-term memory capacities.

Primary osteosarcoma of the lung.  Report of two cases and review of the literature. Primary osteosarcoma of the lung is an extremely rare and aggressive malignancy. We report two cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung and review the existing literature on this topic. The first case involved a 45-year-old male who presented with cough, hemoptysis, and pleuritic chest pain. Imaging revealed a large mass in the right lung with pleural invasion. The second case involved a 56-year-old female who presented with dyspnea and was found to have a large lung mass on imaging. Both patients underwent surgical resection of the lung mass, and histopathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. Both patients received adjuvant chemotherapy, but unfortunately, they experienced disease progression and succumbed to their illness within a year from diagnosis. Review of the literature revealed limited cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung, with most cases presenting in the fifth to sixth decade of life. The prognosis for this rare malignancy remains extremely poor, emphasizing the need for further research and effective treatment options.

Diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus. We report a case of diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The patient presented with recurrent infections despite adequate antiretroviral therapy and had persistently low levels of immunoglobulin G (IgG). Further evaluation revealed normal B-cell counts and absence of other causes of hypogammaglobulinemia. The patient had been on diphenylhydantoin for the treatment of seizures. After discontinuation of diphenylhydantoin, there was a gradual improvement in IgG levels and a decrease in the frequency of infections. This case highlights the importance of considering drug-induced immunodeficiency as a potential cause of recurrent infections in HIV-infected individuals and emphasizes the need for close monitoring of immunoglobulin levels in such patients.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a complex condition with various underlying causes, making it challenging to diagnose and treat effectively. This article aims to explore the anatomical and physiological aspects of the pelvis that contribute to the understanding of pelvic pain. The pelvic region houses vital organs such as the bladder, uterus, and rectum, which are interconnected through a network of nerves and blood vessels. Understanding the intricate anatomy of these structures, including their physiological functions, is crucial in identifying potential sources of pelvic pain. Dysfunctions in the musculoskeletal, neurologic, and vascular systems can all contribute to the perception of pelvic pain. By integrating knowledge of anatomy and physiology, clinicians can develop comprehensive treatment strategies to address the underlying etiology and provide relief to patients suffering from pelvic pain.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. The optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets in the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea were investigated. A total of 200 children aged 6 months to 5 years with acute diarrhea were included in the study. The children were randomly assigned to two intervention groups: early feeding group and delayed feeding group. The early feeding group received oral rehydration solution (ORS) along with breastfeeding or age-appropriate solid foods immediately after diagnosis, while the delayed feeding group received ORS alone for the first 24 hours. The results showed that early feeding was associated with a significantly shorter duration of diarrhea compared to delayed feeding (mean difference 0.7 days, p<0.001). There were no significant differences in the frequency of vomiting or the occurrence of complications between the two groups. In terms of milk type, both breast milk and specially formulated milks were found to be suitable for diarrhea management, while mixed diets were not recommended due to their higher osmolarity and potential adverse effects on gut function. Overall, this study highlights the importance of early feeding and appropriate milk choices in the management of acute childhood diarrhea.

Small bowel phytobezoar mimicking presentation of Crohn's disease. A 42-year-old female presented with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and tenesmus that lasted for several months. The symptoms and radiographic findings raised concerns for Crohn's disease. However, further investigation revealed a large small bowel phytobezoar as the cause of her symptoms. This was successfully removed via endoscopic intervention. Phytobezoars are rare in the small bowel and often present with nonspecific symptoms, making diagnosis challenging. This case highlights the importance of considering phytobezoar as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms mimicking Crohn's disease, particularly in those with a history of poor mastication or ingestion of high-fiber foods. Early recognition and appropriate intervention can prevent unnecessary procedures and guide appropriate management.

Child care practices with respect to acute respiratory tract infection in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. This study aimed to investigate child care practices related to acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. A cross-sectional survey was conducted among caregivers of children under five years old. Information regarding child care practices, including breastfeeding, hand hygiene, and use of traditional remedies, was collected through structured interviews. The prevalence of ARTIs among the children was also assessed.

The results showed that breastfeeding rates were suboptimal, with only 45% of children exclusively breastfed for the recommended six months. Hand hygiene practices were poor, with less than 30% of caregivers reporting regular handwashing before food preparation or feeding. Interestingly, traditional remedies were commonly used by caregivers for treating ARTIs, with 70% reporting the use of herbal preparations.

These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to improve child care practices in this community. Emphasizing the importance of exclusive breastfeeding, promoting proper hand hygiene, and providing education on evidence-based treatment options can potentially reduce the burden of ARTIs among young children in resource-poor settings.

Pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G. III. Neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G are proteases released by activated neutrophils and play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis (AIA). This study aimed to investigate the contribution of neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G in AIA by using mice deficient in these proteases.

Mice lacking neutrophil elastase (NEKO) and cathepsin G (CGKO) were compared to wild-type (WT) mice in their response to antigen-induced arthritis. Joint swelling and histopathological changes were evaluated after receiving intra-articular injections of methylated bovine serum albumin (mBSA). NEKO and CGKO mice exhibited significantly reduced joint swelling and histopathological changes compared to WT mice. Furthermore, reduced neutrophil infiltration and decreased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines were observed in NEKO and CGKO mice.

These findings suggest that neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G are critical mediators in the pathogenesis of AIA. Inhibition of these proteases may provide potential therapeutic interventions for the treatment of arthritis.

Prospective payment system and impairment at discharge. Prospective payment systems (PPS) have been implemented in healthcare settings to provide a standardized method of reimbursement for medical services. However, there is limited research on the impact of PPS on patient outcomes, particularly in terms of impairment at discharge. This retrospective study aimed to assess the relationship between PPS and impairment at discharge in a sample of hospitalized patients. 

Data from electronic health records of patients discharged from a hospital between 2015 and 2017 were analyzed. Impairment at discharge was measured using a standardized assessment tool. PPS status was determined based on the reimbursement mechanism used for each patient. 

Results showed that patients under PPS had a higher prevalence of impairment at discharge compared to those under fee-for-service payment systems. This association remained significant after adjusting for potential confounders such as age, comorbidities, and length of hospital stay. 

These findings suggest that PPS may be associated with increased impairment at discharge, highlighting the need for further research on the impact of reimbursement systems on patient outcomes. Improved understanding of this relationship can inform policy decisions aimed at optimizing healthcare delivery and patient outcomes.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. The authors conducted a study to evaluate the relationship between flow cytometric DNA content, histologic features, and prognosis in patients with adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland. Twenty-three patients with ACC were included in the study. Flow cytometry was performed on tumor specimens to assess DNA content. Histologic features, including tumor grade, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion, were correlated with DNA content. The findings revealed a significant association between DNA content and tumor grade, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion. Patients with high DNA content had higher tumor grade and increased rates of perineural invasion and lymphovascular invasion. Furthermore, patients with high DNA content had a poorer prognosis compared to those with low DNA content. This study highlights the potential utility of flow cytometric DNA content as a prognostic marker in ACC of the submandibular gland.

Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots. Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots is a common condition that can cause significant pain and functional impairment. This study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of this condition. Twenty patients with clinically suspected compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots were included in the study. All patients underwent high-resolution MRI of the spinal cord and nerve roots. The MRI images revealed a variety of findings, including nerve root compression, foraminal stenosis, and nerve root thickening. These findings were consistent with the patients' clinical symptoms and correlated well with the physical examination findings. MRI was found to be a valuable tool in the diagnosis of compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots, allowing for accurate localization and assessment of the extent of nerve root involvement. This information can guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes.

Prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after onset of diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Proteinuria, characterized by the presence of excess protein in urine, has been recognized as a significant marker for renal dysfunction and poor prognosis in various renal disorders. However, its prognostic significance in diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome (D+HUS) remains unclear. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of proteinuria one year after the onset of D+HUS. Medical records of 117 pediatric patients with D+HUS were reviewed, and clinical and laboratory data were collected. Proteinuria was measured using a urinary protein/creatinine ratio. Results showed that patients with persistent proteinuria one year after D+HUS onset had a significantly higher incidence of acute kidney injury, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease compared to those without proteinuria. Furthermore, persistent proteinuria was associated with a poorer renal outcome and increased risk of renal replacement therapy. These findings emphasize the importance of monitoring proteinuria in D+HUS patients to identify those at higher risk of renal complications and to tailor their management accordingly.

Vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN: clinical and pathological features and management. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities are commonly observed in patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). However, there is limited information available on the clinical and pathological features of these abnormalities, as well as their optimal management. In this study, we aimed to investigate the characteristics and treatment options for vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients diagnosed with CIN and concurrent vaginal epithelial abnormalities between 2005 and 2015. The clinical and pathological features of these cases were examined, and various management strategies were evaluated. The results revealed that the majority of patients presented with abnormal vaginal discharge and itching, with a significant association between the extent of vaginal epithelial abnormalities and the severity of CIN. Treatment options included local excision, laser ablation, and vaginal trichloroacetic acid application. Overall, effective management of vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN requires a comprehensive approach that considers both the clinical and pathological aspects of the condition.

Effect of exposure of miners to aluminium powder. Exposure to aluminium powder has been associated with various respiratory ailments and occupational hazards in miners. This study aims to investigate the effects of aluminium powder exposure on the respiratory health of miners. A cohort of miners exposed to aluminium powder and a control group of non-exposed individuals were recruited for this study. Detailed medical histories, including respiratory symptoms and lung function tests, were collected from both groups. The results showed a higher prevalence of respiratory symptoms, such as cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing, in the exposed group compared to the control group. Additionally, lung function tests revealed a significant decline in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC) in the exposed group. These findings suggest that exposure to aluminium powder is associated with respiratory impairment in miners and highlights the need for effective preventive measures to minimize exposure and protect the respiratory health of workers.
